name: Book of Genesis
desc: This book is so called from its treating of the GENERATION, that is, of the creation and the beginning of the world.  The Hebrews call it BERESITH, from the Word with which it begins.  It contains not only the history of the Creation of the world; but also an account of its progress during the space of 2369 years, that is, until the death of JOSEPH.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 1
ch.desc: God createth Heaven and Earth, and all things therein, in six days.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 2
ch.desc: God resteth on the seventh day and blesseth it.  The earthly paradise, in which God placeth man.  He commandeth him not to eat of the tree of knowledge.  And formeth a woman of his rib.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 3
ch.desc: The serpent's craft.  The fall of our first parents.  Their punishment. The promise of a Redeemer.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 4
ch.desc: The history of Cain and Abel.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 5
ch.desc: The genealogy, age, and death of the Patriarchs, from Adam to Noe.  The translation of Henoch.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 6
ch.desc: Man's sin is the cause of the deluge.  Noe is commanded to build the ark.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 7
ch.desc: Noe with his family go into the ark.  The deluge overflows the earth.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 8
ch.desc: The deluge ceaseth.  Noe goeth out of the ark, and offereth a sacrifice. God's covenant to him.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 9
ch.desc: God blesseth Noe:  forbiddeth blood, and promiseth never more to destroy the world by water.  The blessing of Sem and Japheth.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 10
ch.desc: The genealogy of the children of Noe, by whom the world was peopled after the flood.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 11
ch.desc: The tower of Babel.  The confusion of tongues.  The genealogy of Sem down to Abram.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 12
ch.desc: The call of Abram, and the promise made to him.  He sojourneth in Chanaan, and then by occasion of a famine, goeth down to Egypt.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 13
ch.desc: Abram and Lot part from each other.  God's promise to Abram.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 14
ch.desc: The expedition of the four kings; the victory of Abram; he is blessed by Melchisedech.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 15
ch.desc: God promiseth seed to Abram.  His faith, sacrifice and vision.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 16
ch.desc: Abram marrieth Agar, who bringeth forth Ismael.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 17
ch.desc: The Covenant of circumcision.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 18
ch.desc: Angels are entertained by Abraham.  They foretell the birth of Isaac. Abraham's prayer for the men of Sodom.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 19
ch.desc: Lot, entertaining Angels in his house, is delivered from Sodom, which is destroyed:  his wife for looking back is turned into a statue of salt.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 20
ch.desc: Abraham sojourned in Gerara:  Sara is taken into king Abimelech's house, but by God's commandment is restored untouched.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 21
ch.desc: Isaac is born.  Agar and Ismael are cast forth.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 22
ch.desc: The faith and obedience of Abraham is proved in his readiness to sacrifice his son Isaac.  He is stayed from the act by an angel.  Former promises are renewed to him.  His brother Nachor's issue.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 23
ch.desc: Sara's death and burial in the field bought of Ephron.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 24
ch.desc: Abraham's servant, sent by him into Mesopotamia, bringeth from thence Rebecca, who is married to Isaac.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 25
ch.desc: Abraham's children by Cetura; his death and that of Ismael.  Isaac hath Esau and Jacob twins.  Esau selleth his first birthright to Jacob.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 26
ch.desc: Isaac sojourneth in Gerara, where God reneweth to him the promise made to Abraham.  King Abimelech maketh league with him.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 27
ch.desc: Jacob, by him mother's counsel, obtaineth his father's blessing instead of Esau.  And by her is advised to fly to his uncle Laban.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 28
ch.desc: Jacob's journey to Mesopotamia:  his vision and vow.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 29
ch.desc: Jacob serveth Laban seven years for Rachel:  but is deceived with Lia: he afterwards marrieth Rachel.  Lia bears him four sons.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 30
ch.desc: Rachel, being barren, delivereth her handmaid to Jacob; she beareth two sons.  Lia ceasing to bear, giveth also her handmaid, and she beareth two more.  Then Lia beareth other two sons and one daughter.  Rachel beareth Joseph.  Jacob, desirous to return home, is hired to stay for a certain part of the flock's increase, whereby he becometh exceeding rich.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 31
ch.desc: Jacob's departure:  he is pursued and overtaken by Laban.  They make a covenant.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 32
ch.desc: Jacob's vision of angels; his message and presents to Esau; his wrestling with an angel.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 33
ch.desc: Jacob and Esau meet:  Jacob goeth to Salem, where he raiseth an altar.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 34
ch.desc: Dina is ravished, for which the Sichemites are destroyed.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 35
ch.desc: Jacob purgeth his family from idols:  goeth by God's commandment to Bethel, and there buildeth an altar.  God appearing again to Jacob blesseth him, and changeth his name into Israel.  Rachel dieth in childbirth.  Isaac also dieth.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 36
ch.desc: Esau with his wives and children parteth from Jacob.  An account of his descendants, and of the first kings of Edom.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 37
ch.desc: Joseph's dreams:  he is sold by his brethren, and carried into Egypt.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 38
ch.desc: The sons of Juda:  the death of Her and Onan:  the birth of Phares and Zara.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 39
ch.desc: Joseph hath charge of his master's house:  rejecteth his mistress's solicitations:  is falsely accused by her, and cast into prison, where he hath the charge of all the prisoners.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 40
ch.desc: Joseph interpreteth the dreams of two of Pharao's servants in prison: the event declareth the interpretations to be true, but Joseph is forgotten.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 41
ch.desc: Joseph interpreteth the two dreams of Pharao:  he is made ruler over all Egypt.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 42
ch.desc: Jacob sendeth his ten sons to buy corn in Egypt.  Their treatment by Joseph.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 43
ch.desc: The sons of Jacob go again into Egypt with Benjamin.  They are entertained by Joseph.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 44
ch.desc: Joseph's contrivance to stop his brethren.  The humble supplication of Juda.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 45
ch.desc: Joseph maketh himself known to his brethren:  and sendeth for his father.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 46
ch.desc: Israel, warranted by a vision from God, goeth down into Egypt with all his family.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 47
ch.desc: Jacob and his sons are presented before Pharao:  he giveth them the land of Gessen.  The famine forceth the Egyptians to sell all their possessions to the king.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 48
ch.desc: Joseph visiteth his father in his sickness, who adopteth his two sons Manasses and Ephraim, and blesseth them, preferring the younger before the elder.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 49
ch.desc: Jacob's prophetical blessings of his twelve sons:  his death.

ch.name: Genesis Chapter 50
ch.desc: The mourning for Jacob, and his interment.  Joseph's kindness towards his brethren.  His death.

name: Book of Exodus
desc: The Second Book of Moses is called EXODUS, from the Greek word EXODOS, which signifies going out:  because it contains the history of the going out of the children of Israel out of Egypt.  The Hebrews, from the words with which it begins, call it VEELLE SEMOTH:  These are the names.  It contains transactions for 145 years; that is, from the death of Joseph to the erecting of the tabernacle.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 1
ch.desc: The Israelites are multiplied in Egypt.  They are oppressed by a new king, who commandeth all their male children to be killed.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 2
ch.desc: Moses is born and exposed on the bank of the river; where he is taken up by the daughter of Pharao, and adopted for her son.  He killeth an Egyptian, and fleeth into Madian; where he marrieth a wife.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 3
ch.desc: God appeareth to Moses in a bush, and sendeth him to deliver Israel.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 4
ch.desc: Moses is empowered to confirm his mission with miracles:  his brother Aaron is appointed to assist him.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 5
ch.desc: Pharao refuseth to let the people go.  They are more oppressed.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 6
ch.desc: God reneweth his promise.  The genealogies of Ruben, Simon and Levi, down to Moses and Aaron. 6;1. And the Lord said to Moses:  Now thou shalt see what I will do to Pharao:  for by a mighty hand shall he let them go, and with a strong hand shall he cast them out of his land.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 7
ch.desc: Moses and Aaron go into Pharao:  they turn the rod into a serpent; and the waters of Egypt into blood, which was the first plague.  The magicians do the like, and Pharao's heart is hardened.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 8
ch.desc: The second plague is of frogs:  Pharao promiseth to let the Israelites go, but breaketh his promise.  The third plague is of sciniphs.  The fourth is of flies.  Pharao again promiseth to dismiss the people, but doth it not.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 9
ch.desc: The fifth plague is a murrain among the cattle.  The sixth, of boils in men and beasts.  The seventh, of hail.  Pharao promiseth again to let the people go, and breaketh his word.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 10
ch.desc: The eighth plague of the locusts.  The ninth, of darkness:  Pharao is still hardened.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 11
ch.desc: Pharao and his people are threatened with the death of their firstborn.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 12
ch.desc: The manner of preparing, and eating the paschal lamb:  the firstborn of Egypt are all slain:  the Israelites depart.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 13
ch.desc: The paschal solemnity is to be observed; and the firstborn are to be consecrated to God.  The people are conducted through the desert by a pillar of fire in the night, and a cloud in the day.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 14
ch.desc: Pharao pursueth the children of Israel.  They murmur against Moses, but are encouraged by him, and pass through the Red Sea.  Pharao and his army following them are drowned.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 15
ch.desc: The canticle of Moses.  The bitter waters of Mara are made sweet.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 16
ch.desc: The people murmur for want of meat:  God giveth them quails and manna.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 17
ch.desc: The people murmur again for want of drink; the Lord giveth them water out of a rock.  Moses lifting up his hand in prayer, Amalec is overcome.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 18
ch.desc: Jethro bringeth to Moses his wife and children.  His counsel.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 19
ch.desc: They come to Sinai:  the people are commanded to be sanctified.  The Lord, coming in thunder and lightning, speaketh with Moses.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 20
ch.desc: The ten commandments.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 21
ch.desc: Laws relating to Justice.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 22
ch.desc: The punishment of theft, and other trespasses.  The law of lending without usury, of taking pledges of reverences to superiors, and of paying tithes.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 23
ch.desc: Laws for judges; the rest of the seventh year, and day:  three principal feasts to be solemnized every year; the promise of an angel, to conduct and protect them:  idols are to be destroyed.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 24
ch.desc: Moses writeth his law; and after offering sacrifices, sprinkleth the blood of the testament upon the people:  then goeth up the mountain which God covereth with a fiery cloud.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 25
ch.desc: Offerings prescribed for making the tabernacle, the ark, the candlestick, etc.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 26
ch.desc: The form of the tabernacle with its appurtenances.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 27
ch.desc: The altar; and the court of the tabernacle with its hangings and pillars.  Provision of oil for lamps.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 28
ch.desc: The holy vestments for Aaron and his sons.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 29
ch.desc: The manner of consecrating Aaron and other priests; the institution of the daily sacrifice of two lambs, one in the morning, the other at evening.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 30
ch.desc: The altar of incense:  money to be gathered for the use of the tabernacle:  the brazen laver:  the holy oil of unction, and the composition of the perfume.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 31
ch.desc: Beseleel and Ooliab are appointed by the Lord to make the tabernacle, and the things belonging thereto.  The observation of the sabbath day is again commanded.  And the Lord delivereth to Moses two tables written with the finger of God.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 32
ch.desc: The people fall into idolatry.  Moses prayeth for them.  He breaketh the tables:  destroyeth the idol:  blameth Aaron, and causeth many of the idolaters to be slain.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 33
ch.desc: The people mourn for their sin.  Moses pitcheth the tabernacle without the camp.  He converseth familiarly with God.  Desireth to see his glory.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 34
ch.desc: The tables are renewed:  all society with the Chanaanites is forbid: some precepts concerning the firstborn, the sabbath, and other feasts: after forty days' fast, Moses returneth to the people with the commandments, and his face appearing horned with rays of light, he covereth it, whensoever he speaketh to the people.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 35
ch.desc: The sabbath.  Offerings for making the tabernacle.  Beseleel and Ooliab are called to the work.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 36
ch.desc: The offerings are delivered to the workmen, the curtains, coverings, boards, bars, veil, pillars, and hanging are made.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 37
ch.desc: Beseleel maketh the ark:  the propitiatory, and cherubims, the table, the candlestick, the lamps, and the altar of incense, and compoundeth the incense.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 38
ch.desc: He maketh the altar of holocaust.  The brazen laver.  The court with its pillars and hangings.  The sum of what the people offered.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 39
ch.desc: All the ornaments of Aaron and his sons are made.  And the whole work of the tabernacle is finished.

ch.name: Exodus Chapter 40
ch.desc: The tabernacle is commanded to be set up and anointed.  God filleth it with his majesty.

name: Book of Leviticus
desc: This Book is called LEVITICUS, because it treats of the Offices, Ministries, Rites and Ceremonies of the Priests and Levites.  The Hebrews call it VAICRA, from the word with which it begins.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 1
ch.desc: Of holocausts or burnt offerings.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 2
ch.desc: Of offerings of flour, and firstfruits.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 3
ch.desc: Of peace offerings.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 4
ch.desc: Of offerings for sins of ignorance.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 5
ch.desc: Of other sacrifices for sins.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 6
ch.desc: Oblation for sins of injustice:  ordinances concerning the holocausts and the perpetual fire:  the sacrifices of the priests, and the sin offerings.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 7
ch.desc: Of sacrifices for trespasses and thanks offerings.  No fat nor blood is to be eaten.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 8
ch.desc: Moses consecrateth Aaron and his sons.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 9
ch.desc: Aaron offereth sacrifice for himself and the people.  Fire cometh from the Lord upon the altar.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 10
ch.desc: Nadab and Abiu for offering strange fire, are burnt by fire.  Priests are forbidden to drink wine, when they enter into the tabernacle.  The law of eating the holy things.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 11
ch.desc: The distinction of clean and unclean animals.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 12
ch.desc: The purification of women after childbirth.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 13
ch.desc: The law concerning leprosy in men, and in garments.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 14
ch.desc: The rites of sacrifices in cleansing the leprosy.  Leprosy in houses.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 15
ch.desc: Other legal uncleannesses.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 16
ch.desc: When and how the high priest must enter into the sanctuary.  The feast of expiation.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 17
ch.desc: No sacrifices to be offered but at the door of the tabernacle:  a prohibition of blood.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 18
ch.desc: Marriage is prohibited in certain degrees of kindred:  Anda all unnatural lusts.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 19
ch.desc: Divers ordinances, partly moral, partly ceremonial or judicial.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 20
ch.desc: Divers crimes to be punished with death.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 21
ch.desc: Ordinances relating to the priests.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 22
ch.desc: Who may eat the holy things:  and what things may be offered.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 23
ch.desc: Holy days to be kept.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 24
ch.desc: The oil for the lamps.  The loaves of proposition.  The punishment of blasphemy.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 25
ch.desc: The law of the seventh and of the fiftieth year of jubilee.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 26
ch.desc: God's promises to them that keep his commandments.  And the many punishments with which he threatens transgressors.

ch.name: Leviticus Chapter 27
ch.desc: Of vows and tithes.

name: Book of Numbers
desc: This fourth Book of Moses is called NUMBERS, because it begins with the numbering of the people.  The Hebrews, from its first words, call it VAIEDABBER.  It contains the transactions of the Israelites from the second month of the second year after their going out of Egypt, until the beginning of the eleventh month of the fortieth year; that is, a history almost of thirty-nine years.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 1
ch.desc: The children of Israel are numbered:  the Levites are designed to serve the tabernacle.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 2
ch.desc: The order of the tribes in their camp.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 3
ch.desc: The Levites are numbered and their offices distinguished.  They are taken in the place of the firstborn of the children of Israel.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 4
ch.desc: The age and time of the Levites' service:  their offices and burdens.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 5
ch.desc: The unclean are removed out of the camp:  confession of sins, and satisfaction:  firstfruits and oblations belonging to the priests:  trial of jealousy.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 6
ch.desc: The law of the Nazarites:  the form of blessing the people.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 7
ch.desc: The offerings of the princes at the dedication of the tabernacle.  God speaketh to Moses from the propitiatory.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 8
ch.desc: The seven lamps are placed on the golden candlestick, to shine towards the loaves of proposition:  the ordination of the Levites:  and to what age they shall serve in the tabernacle.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 9
ch.desc: The precept of the pasch is renewed:  the unclean and travellers are to observe it the second month:  the camp is guided by the pillar of the cloud.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 10
ch.desc: The silver trumpets and their use.  They march from Sinai.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 11
ch.desc: The people murmur and are punished with fire.  God appointeth seventy ancients for assistants to Moses.  They prophesy.  The people have their fill of flesh, but forthwith many die of the plague.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 12
ch.desc: Mary and Aaron murmur against Moses, whom God praiseth above other prophets.  Mary being struck with leprosy, Aaron confesseth his fault. Moses prayeth for her, and after seven days' separation from the camp, she is restored.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 13
ch.desc: The twelve spies are sent to view the land.  The relation they make of it.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 14
ch.desc: The people murmur.  God threateneth to destroy them.  He is appeased by Moses, yet so as to exclude the murmurers from entering the promised land.  The authors of the sedition are struck dead.  The rest going to fight against the will of God are beaten.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 15
ch.desc: Certain laws concerning sacrifices.  Sabbath breaking is punished with death.  The law of fringes on their garments.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 16
ch.desc: The schism of Core and his adherents:  their punishment.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 17
ch.desc: The priesthood is confirmed to Aaron by the miracle of the blooming of his rod, which is kept for a monument in the tabernacle.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 18
ch.desc: The charge of the priests and of the Levites, and their portion.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 19
ch.desc: The law of the sacrifice of the red cow, and the water of expiation.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 20
ch.desc: The death of Mary the sister of Moses.  The people murmur for want of water:  God giveth it them from the rock.  The death of Aaron.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 21
ch.desc: King Arad is overcome.  The people murmur and are punished with fiery serpents:  they are healed by the brazen serpent.  They conquer the kings Sehon and Og.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 22
ch.desc: Balac, king of Moab, sendeth twice for Balaam to curse Israel.  In his way Balaam is rebuked by an angel.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 23
ch.desc: Balaam, instead of cursing Israel, is obliged to bless them, and prophesy good things of them.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 24
ch.desc: Balaam still continues to prophesy good things in favour of Israel.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 25
ch.desc: The people fall into fornication and idolatry; for which twenty-four thousand are slain.  The zeal of Phinees.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 26
ch.desc: The people are again numbered by their tribes and families.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 27
ch.desc: The law of inheritance.  Josue is appointed to succeed Moses.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 28
ch.desc: Sacrifices are appointed as well for every day as for sabbaths, and other festivals.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 29
ch.desc: Sacrifices for the festivals of the seventh month.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 30
ch.desc: Of vows and oaths:  and their obligation.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 31
ch.desc: The Madianites are slain for having drawn the people of Israel into sin.  The dividing of the booty.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 32
ch.desc: The tribes of Ruben and Gad, and half of the tribe of Manasses, receive their inheritance on the east side of Jordan, upon conditions approved of by Moses.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 33
ch.desc: The mansions or journeys of the children of Israel towards the land of promise.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 34
ch.desc: The limits of Chanaan; with the names of the men that make the division of it.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 35
ch.desc: Cities are appointed for the Levites.  Of which six are to be the cities of refuge.

ch.name: Numbers Chapter 36
ch.desc: That the inheritances may not be alienated from one tribe to another, all are to marry within their own tribes.

name: Book of Deuteronomy
desc: This Book is called DEUTERONOMY, which signifies a SECOND LAW, because it repeats and inculcates the ordinances formerly given on mount Sinai, with other precepts not expressed before.  The Hebrews, from the first words in the book, call it ELLE HADDEBARIM.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 1
ch.desc: A repetition of what passed at Sinai and Cadesbarne:  and of the people's murmuring and their punishment.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 2
ch.desc: They are forbid to fight against the Edomites, Moabites, and Ammonites. Their victory over Sehon king of Hesebon.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 3
ch.desc: The victory over Og king of Basan.  Ruben, Gad, and half the tribe of Manasses receive their possession on the other side of Jordan.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 4
ch.desc: Moses exhorteth the people to keep God's commandments:  particularly to fly idolatry.  Appointeth three cities of refuge, on that side of the Jordan.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 5
ch.desc: The ten commandments are repeated and explained.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 6
ch.desc: An exhortation to the love of God, and obedience to his law.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 7
ch.desc: No league nor fellowship to be made with the Chanaanites:  God promiseth his people his blessing and assistance, if they keep his commandments.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 8
ch.desc: The people is put in mind of God's dealings with them, to the end that they may love him and serve him.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 9
ch.desc: Lest they should impute their victories to their own merits, they are put in mind of their manifold rebellions and other sins, for which they should have been destroyed, but God spared them for his promise made to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 10
ch.desc: God giveth the second tables of the law:  a further exhortation to fear and serve the Lord.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 11
ch.desc: The love and service of God are still inculcated, with a blessing to them that serve him, and threats of punishment if they forsake his law.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 12
ch.desc: All idolatry must be extirpated:  sacrifices, tithes, and firstfruits must be offered in one only place:  all eating of blood is prohibited.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 13
ch.desc: False prophets must be slain, and idolatrous cities destroyed.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 14
ch.desc: In mourning for the dead they are not to follow the ways of the Gentiles:  the distinction of clean and unclean meats:  ordinances concerning tithes, and firstfruits.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 15
ch.desc: The law of the seventh year of remission.  The firstlings of cattle are to be sanctified to the Lord.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 16
ch.desc: The three principal solemnities to be observed:  just judges to be appointed in every city:  all occasions of idolatry to be avoided.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 17
ch.desc: Victims must be without blemish.  Idolaters are to be slain. Controversies are to be decided by the high priest and council, whose sentence must be obeyed under pain of death.  The duty of a king, who is to receive the law of God at the priest's hands.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 18
ch.desc: The Lord is the inheritance of the priests and Levites.  Heathenish abominations are to be avoided.  The great PROPHET CHRIST is promised. False prophets must be slain.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 19
ch.desc: The cities of refuge.  Wilful murder, and false witnesses must be punished.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 20
ch.desc: Laws relating to war.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 21
ch.desc: The expiation of a secret murder.  The marrying a captive.  The eldest son must not be deprived of his birthright for hatred of his mother.  A stubborn son is to be stoned to death.  When one is hanged on a gibbet, he must be taken down the same day and buried.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 22
ch.desc: Humanity towards neighbours.  Neither sex may use the apparel of the other.  Cruelty to be avoided even to birds.  Battlements about the roof of a house.  Things of divers kinds not to be mixed.  The punishment of him that slandereth his wife, as also of adultery and rape.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 23
ch.desc: Who may and who may not enter into the church:  uncleanness to be avoided:  other precepts concerning fugitives, fornication, usury, vows, and eating other men's grapes and corn.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 24
ch.desc: Divorce permitted to avoid greater evil:  the newly married must not go to war:  of men stealers, of leprosy, of pledges, of labourers' hire, of justice, and of charity to the poor.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 25
ch.desc: Stripes must not exceed forty.  The ox is not to be muzzled.  Of raising seed to the brother.  Of the immodest woman.  Of unjust weight.  Of destroying the Amalecites.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 26
ch.desc: The form of words with which the firstfruits and tithes are to be offered.  God's covenant.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 27
ch.desc: The commandments must be written on stones:  and an altar erected, and sacrifices offered.  The observers of the commandments are to be blessed, and the transgressors cursed.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 28
ch.desc: Many blessings are promised to observers of God's commandments:  and curses threatened to transgressors.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 29
ch.desc: The covenant is solemnly confirmed between God and his people.  Threats against those that shall break it.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 30
ch.desc: Great mercies are promised to the penitent:  God's commandment is feasible.  Life and death are set before them.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 31
ch.desc: Moses encourageth the people, and Josue, who is appointed to succeed him.  He delivereth the law to the priests.  God foretelleth that the people will often forsake him, and that he will punish them.  He commandeth Moses to write a canticle, as a constant remembrancer of the law.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 32
ch.desc: A canticle for the remembrance of the law.  Moses is commanded to go up into a mountain, from whence he shall see the promised land but not enter into it.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 33
ch.desc: Moses before his death blesseth the tribes of Israel.

ch.name: Deuteronomy Chapter 34
ch.desc: Moses seeth the promised land, but is not suffered to go into it.  He dieth at the age of 120 years.  God burieth his body secretly, and all Israel mourn for him thirty days.  Josue, replenished (by imposition of Moses's hands) with the spirit of God, succeedeth.  But Moses, for his special familiarity with God, and for most wonderful miracles, is commended above all other prophets.

name: Book of Josue
desc: This Book is called JOSUE, because it contains the history of what passed under him, and according to the common opinion was written by him.  The Greeks call him Jesus:  for Josue and Jesus in the Hebrew, are the same name, and have the same signification, viz., A SAVIOUR.  And it was not without a mystery that he who was to bring the people into the land of promise should have his name changed from OSEE (for so he was called before, Num. 13.17,) to JOSUE or JESUS, to give us to understand, that Moses by his law could only bring the people within sight of the promised inheritance, but that our Saviour JESUS was to bring us into it.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 1
ch.desc: Josue, encouraged by the Lord, admonisheth the people to prepare themselves to pass over the Jordan.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 2
ch.desc: Two spies are sent to Jericho, who are received and concealed by Rahab.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 3
ch.desc: The river Jordan is miraculously dried up for the passage of the children of Israel.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 4
ch.desc: Twelve stones are taken out of the river to be set up for a monument of the miracle; and other twelve are placed in the midst of the river.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 5
ch.desc: The people are circumcised:  they keep the pasch.  The manna ceaseth.  An angel appeareth to Josue.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 6
ch.desc: After seven days' processions, the priests sounding the trumpets, the walls of Jericho fall down:  and the city is taken and destroyed.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 7
ch.desc: For the sins of Achan, the Israelites are defeated at Hai.  The offender is found out; and stoned to death, and God's wrath is turned from them.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 8
ch.desc: Hai is taken and burnt, and all the inhabitants slain.  An altar is built, and sacrifices offered.  The law is written on stones, and the blessings and cursings are read before all the people.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 9
ch.desc: Josue is deceived by the Gabaonites:  who being detected are condemned to be perpetual servants.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 10
ch.desc: Five kings war against Gabaon.  Josue defeateth them:  many are slain with hailstones.  At the prayer of Josue the sun and moon stand still the space of one day.  The five kings are hanged.  Divers cities are taken.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 11
ch.desc: The kings of the north are overthrown:  the whole country is taken.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 12
ch.desc: A list of the kings slain by Moses and Josue,

ch.name: Josue Chapter 13
ch.desc: God commandeth Josue to divide the land:  the possessions of Ruben, Gad, and half the tribe of Manasses, beyond the Jordan.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 14
ch.desc: Caleb's petition; Hebron is given to him and to his seed.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 15
ch.desc: The borders of the lot of Juda.  Caleb's portion and conquest.  The cities of Juda.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 16
ch.desc: The lot of the sons of Joseph.  The borders of the tribe of Ephraim.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 17
ch.desc: The lot of the half tribe of Manasses.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 18
ch.desc: Surveyors are sent to divide the rest of the land into seven tribes. The lot of Benjamin.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 19
ch.desc: The lots of the tribes of Simeon, Zabulon, Issachar, Aser, Nephtali and Dan.  A city is given to Josue.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 20
ch.desc: The cities of refuge are appointed for casual manslaughter.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 21
ch.desc: Cities with their suburbs are assigned for the priests and Levites.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 22
ch.desc: The tribes of Ruben and Gad, and half the tribe of Manasses return to their possessions.  They build an altar by the side of the Jordan, which alarms the other tribes.  An embassage is sent to them, to which they give a satisfactory answer.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 23
ch.desc: Josue being old admonisheth the people to keep God's commandments:  and to avoid marriages and all society with the Gentiles for fear of being brought to idolatry.

ch.name: Josue Chapter 24
ch.desc: Josue assembleth the people, and reneweth the covenant between them and God.  His death and burial.

name: Book of Judges
desc: This Book is called JUDGES, because it contains the history of what passed under the government of the judges, who ruled Israel before they had kings.  The writer of it, according to the more general opinion, was the prophet Samuel.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 1
ch.desc: The expedition and victory of Juda against the Chanaanites:  who are tolerated in many places.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 2
ch.desc: An angel reproveth Israel.  They weep for their sins.  After the death of Josue, they often fall, and repenting are delivered from their afflictions, but still fall worse and worse.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 3
ch.desc: The people falling into idolatry are oppressed by their enemies; but repenting are delivered by Othoniel, Aod, and Samgar.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 4
ch.desc: Debbora and Barac deliver Israel from Jabin and Sisara, Jahal killeth Sisara.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 5
ch.desc: The canticle of Debbora and Barac after their victory.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 6
ch.desc: The people for their sins, are oppressed by the Madianites.  Gedeon is called to deliver them.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 7
ch.desc: Gedeon, with three hundred men, by stratagem defeateth the Madianites.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 8
ch.desc: Gedeon appeaseth the Ephraimites.  Taketh Zebee and Salmana.  Destroyeth Soccoth and Phanuel.  Refuseth to be king.  Maketh an ephod of the gold of the prey, and dieth in a good old age.  The people return to idolatry.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 9
ch.desc: Abimelech killeth his brethren.  Joatham's parable.  Gaal conspireth with the Sichemites against Abimelech, but is overcome.  Abimelech destroyeth Sichem:  but is killed at Thebes.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 10
ch.desc: Thola ruleth Israel twenty-three years; and Jair twenty-two.  The people fall again into idolatry, and are afflicted again by the Philistines and Ammonites.  They cry to God for help, who upon their repentance hath compassion on them.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 11
ch.desc: Jephte is made ruler of the people of Galaad:  he first pleads their cause against the Ammonites; then making a vow obtains a signal victory; he performs his vow.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 12
ch.desc: The Ephraimites quarrel with Jephte:  forty-two thousand of them are slain:  Abeson, Ahialon, and Abdon, are judges.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 13
ch.desc: The people fall again into idolatry and are afflicted by the Philistines.  An angel foretelleth the birth of Samson.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 14
ch.desc: Samson desireth a wife of the Philistines.  He killeth a lion:  in whose mouth he afterwards findeth honey.  His marriage feast, and riddle, which is discovered by his wife.  He killeth, and strippeth thirty Philistines.  His wife taketh another man.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 15
ch.desc: Samson is denied his wife.  He burns the corn of the Philistines, and kills many of them.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 16
ch.desc: Samson is deluded by Dalila:  and falls into the hands of the Philistines.  His death.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 17
ch.desc: The history of the idol of Michas, and the young Levite.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 18
ch.desc: The expedition of the men of Dan against Lais:  in their way they rob Michas of his priest and his gods.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 19
ch.desc: A Levite bringing home his wife, is lodged by an old man at Gabaa in the tribe of Benjamin.  His wife is there abused by wicked men, and in the morning found dead.  Her husband cutteth her body in pieces, and sendeth to every tribe of Israel, requiring them to revenge the wicked fact.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 20
ch.desc: The Israelites warring against Benjamin are twice defeated; but in the third battle the Benjamites are all slain, saving six hundred men.

ch.name: Judges Chapter 21
ch.desc: The tribe of Benjamin is saved from being utterly extinct, by providing wives for the six hundred that remained.

name: Book of Ruth
desc: This Book is called RUTH, from the name of the person whose history is here recorded:  who, being a Gentile, became a convert to the true faith, and marrying Booz, the great-grandfather of David, was one of those from whom Christ sprung according to the flesh, and an illustrious figure of the Gentile church.  It is thought this book was written by the prophet Samuel.

ch.name: Ruth Chapter 1
ch.desc: Elimelech of Bethlehem going with his wife Noemi, and two sons, into the land of Moab, dieth there.  His sons marry wives of that country and die without issue.  Noemi returneth home with her daughter in law Ruth, who refuseth to part with her.

ch.name: Ruth Chapter 2
ch.desc: Ruth gleaneth in the field of Booz, who sheweth her favour.

ch.name: Ruth Chapter 3
ch.desc: Ruth instructed by her mother in law lieth at Booz's feet, claiming him for her husband by the law of affinity:  she receiveth a good answer, and six measures of barley.

ch.name: Ruth Chapter 4
ch.desc: Upon the refusal of the nearer kinsman, Booz marrieth Ruth, who bringeth forth Obed, the grandfather of David.

name: First Book of Samuel
fmlname: THE FIRST BOOK OF SAMUEL, OTHERWISE CALLED THE FIRST BOOK OF KINGS
desc: This and the following Book are called by the Hebrews the books of Samuel, because they contain the history of Samuel, and of the two kings, Saul and David, whom he anointed.  They are more commonly named by the Fathers, the first and second book of kings.  As to the writer of them, it is the common opinion that Samuel composed the first book, as far as the twenty-fifth chapter; and that the prophets Nathan and Gad finished the first, and wrote the second book.  See 1 Paralipomenon, alias 1 Chronicles, 29.29.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 1
ch.desc: Anna the wife of Elcana being barren, by vow and prayer obtaineth a son:  whom she calleth Samuel:  and presenteth him to the service of God in Silo, according to her vow.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 2
ch.desc: The canticle of Anna.  The wickedness of the sons of Heli:  for which they are not duly corrected by their father.  A prophecy against the house of Heli.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 3
ch.desc: Samuel is four times called by the Lord:  who revealeth to him the evil that shall fall on Heli, and his house.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 4
ch.desc: The Israelites being overcome by the Philistines, send for the ark of God:  but they are beaten again, the sons of Heli are killed, and the ark taken:  upon the hearing of the news Heli falleth backward and dieth.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 5
ch.desc: Dagon twice falleth down before the ark.  The Philistines are grievously afflicted, wherever the ark cometh.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 6
ch.desc: The ark is sent back to Bethsames:  where many are slain for looking through curiosity into it.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 7
ch.desc: The ark is brought to Cariathiarim.  By Samuel's exhortation the people cast away their idols and serve God alone.  The Lord defeateth the Philistines, while Samuel offereth sacrifice.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 8
ch.desc: Samuel growing old, and his sons not walking in his ways, the people desire a king.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 9
ch.desc: Saul seeking his father's asses, cometh to Samuel, by whom he is entertained.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 10
ch.desc: Saul is anointed.  He prophesieth, and is changed into another man. Samuel calleth the people together, to make a king:  the lot falleth on Saul.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 11
ch.desc: Saul defeateth the Ammonites, and delivereth Jabes Galaad.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 12
ch.desc: Samuel's integrity is acknowledged.  God sheweth by a sign from heaven that they had done ill in asking for a king.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 13
ch.desc: The war between Saul and the Philistines.  The distress of the Israelites.  Saul offereth sacrifice before the coming of Samuel:  for which he is reproved.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 14
ch.desc: Jonathan attacketh the Philistines.  A miraculous victory.  Saul's unadvised oath, by which Jonathan is put in danger of his life, but is delivered by the people.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 15
ch.desc: Saul is sent to destroy Amalec:  he spareth their king and the best of their cattle:  for which disobedience he is cast off by the Lord.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 16
ch.desc: Samuel is sent to Bethlehem, where he anointeth David:  who is taken into Saul's family.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 17
ch.desc: War with the Philistines.  Goliath challengeth Israel.  He is slain by David.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 18
ch.desc: The friendship of Jonathan and David.  The envy of Saul, and his design upon David's life.  He marrieth him to his daughter Michol.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 19
ch.desc: Other attempts of Saul upon David's life.  He cometh to Samuel.  Saul's messengers, and Saul himself prophesy.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 20
ch.desc: Saul being obstinately bent upon killing David, he is sent away by Jonathan.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 21
ch.desc: David receiveth holy bread of Achimelech, the priest:  and feigneth himself mad before Achis, king of Geth.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 22
ch.desc: Many resort to David.  Doeg accuseth Achimelech to Saul.  He ordereth him and all the other priests of Nobe to be slain.  Abiathar escapeth.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 23
ch.desc: David relieveth Ceila, besieged by the Philistines.  He fleeth into the desert of Ziph.  Jonathan and he confirm their former covenant.  The Ziphites discover him to Saul, who pursuing close after him, is called away by an invasion from the Philistines.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 24
ch.desc: Saul seeketh David in the wilderness of Engaddi:  he goeth into a cave where David hath him in his power.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 25
ch.desc: The death of Samuel.  David, provoked by Nabal, threateneth to destroy him:  but is appeased by Abigail.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 26
ch.desc: Saul goeth out again after David, who cometh by night where Saul and his men are asleep, but suffereth him not to be touched.  Saul again confesseth his fault, and promiseth peace.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 27
ch.desc: David goeth again to Achis king of Geth, and obtaineth of him the city of Siceleg.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 28
ch.desc: The Philistines go out to war against Israel.  Saul being forsaken by God, hath recourse to a witch.  Samuel appeareth to him.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 29
ch.desc: David going with the Philistines is sent back by their princes.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 30
ch.desc: The Amalecites burn Siceleg, and carry off the prey:  David pursueth after them, and recovereth all out of their hands.

ch.name: 1 Kings Chapter 31
ch.desc: Israel is defeated by the Philistines:  Saul and his sons are slain.

name: Second Book of Samuel
fmlname: THE SECOND BOOK OF SAMUEL, OTHERWISE CALLED THE SECOND BOOK OF KINGS
desc: This Book relates the transactions from the death of Saul until the end of David's reign, being a history for the space of about forty-six years.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 1
ch.desc: David mourneth for the death of Saul and Jonathan:  he ordereth the man to be slain who pretended he had killed Saul.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 2
ch.desc: David is received and anointed king of Juda.  Isboseth the son of Saul reigneth over the rest of Israel.  A battle between Abner and Joab.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 3
ch.desc: David groweth daily stronger.  Abner cometh over to him:  he is treacherously slain by Joab.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 4
ch.desc: Isboseth is murdered by two of his servants.  David punisheth the murderers.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 5
ch.desc: David is anointed king of all Israel.  He taketh Jerusalem, and dwelleth there.  He defeateth the Philistines.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 6
ch.desc: David fetcheth the ark from Cariathiarim.  Oza is struck dead for touching it.  It is deposited in the house of Obededom:  and from thence carried to David's house.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 7
ch.desc: David's purpose to build a temple is rewarded with the promise of great blessings in his seed:  his prayer and thanksgiving.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 8
ch.desc: David's victories, and his chief officers.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 9
ch.desc: David's kindness to Miphiboseth for the sake of his father Jonathan.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 10
ch.desc: The Ammonites shamefully abuse the ambassadors of David:  they hire the Syrians to the their assistance:  but are overthrown with their allies.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 11
ch.desc: David falleth into the crime of adultery with Bethsabee:  and not finding other means to conceal it, causeth her husband Urias to be slain.  Then marrieth her, who beareth him a son.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 12
ch.desc: Nathan's parable.  David confesseth his sin, and is forgiven:  yet so as to be sentenced to most severe temporal punishments.  The death of the child.  The birth of Solomon.  The taking of Rabbath.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 13
ch.desc: Ammon ravisheth Thamar.  For which Absalom killeth him, and flieth to Gessur.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 14
ch.desc: Joab procureth Absalom's return, and his admittance to the king's presence.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 15
ch.desc: Absalom's policy and conspiracy.  David is obliged to flee.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 16
ch.desc: Siba bringeth provisions to David.  Semei curseth him.  Absalom defileth his father's wives.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 17
ch.desc: Achitophel's counsel is defeated by Chusai:  who sendeth intelligence to David.  Achitophel hangeth himself.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 18
ch.desc: Absalom is defeated, and slain by Joab.  David mourneth for him.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 19
ch.desc: David, at the remonstrances of Joab, ceaseth his mourning.  He is invited back and met by Semei and Miphiboseth:  a strife between the men of Juda and the men of Israel.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 20
ch.desc: Seba's rebellion.  Amasa is slain by Joab.  Abela is besieged, but upon the citizens casting over the wall the head of Seba, Joab departeth with all his army.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 21
ch.desc: A famine of three years, for the sin of Saul against the Gabaonites, at whose desire seven of Saul's race are crucified.  War again with the Philistines.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 22
ch.desc: King David's psalm of thanksgiving for his deliverance from all his enemies.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 23
ch.desc: The last words of David.  A catalogue of his valiant men.

ch.name: 2 Kings Chapter 24
ch.desc: David numbereth the people:  God sendeth a pestilence, which is stopt by David's prayer and sacrifice.

name: Third Book of Kings
desc: This and the following Book are called by the holy fathers the third and fourth book of Kings; but by the Hebrews, the first and second. They contain the history of the kingdoms of Israel and Juda, from the beginning of the reign of Solomon, to the captivity.  As to the writer of these books, it seems most probable they were not written by one man; nor at one time; but as there was all along a succession of prophets in Israel, who recorded, by divine inspiration, the most remarkable things that happened in their days, these books seem to have been written by these prophets.  See 2 Paralip. alias 2 Chron. 9.29; 12.15; 13.22; 20.34; 26.22; 32.32.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 1
ch.desc: King David growing old, Abisag a Sunamitess is brought to him.  Adonias pretending to reign, Nathan and Bethsabee obtain that Solomon should be declared and anointed king.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 2
ch.desc: David, after giving his last charge to Solomon, dieth.  Adonias is put to death:  Abiathar is banished:  Joab and Semei are slain.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 3
ch.desc: Solomon marrieth Pharao's daughter.  He sacrificeth in Gabaon:  in the choice which God gave him he preferreth wisdom.  His wise judgment between the two harlots.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 4
ch.desc: Solomon's chief officers.  His riches and wisdom.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 5
ch.desc: Hiram king of Tyre agreeth to furnish timber and workmen for building the temple:  the number of workmen and overseers.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 6
ch.desc: The building of Solomon's temple.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 7
ch.desc: Solomon's palace, his house in the forest, and the queen's house:  the work of the two pillars:  the sea (or laver) and other vessels.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 8
ch.desc: The dedication of the temple:  Solomon's prayer and sacrifices.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 9
ch.desc: The Lord appeareth again to Solomon:  he buildeth cities:  he sendeth a fleet to Ophir.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 10
ch.desc: The queen of Saba cometh to king Solomon:  his riches and glory.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 11
ch.desc: Solomon by means of his wives falleth into idolatry:  God raiseth him adversaries, Adad, Razon, and Jeroboam:  Solomon dieth.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 12
ch.desc: Roboam, following the counsel of young men alienateth from him the minds of the people.  They make Jeroboam king over ten tribes:  he setteth up idolatry.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 13
ch.desc: A prophet sent from Juda to Bethel foretelleth the birth of Josias, and the destruction of Jeroboam's altar.  Jeroboam's hand offering violence to the prophet withereth, but is restored by the prophet's prayer:  the same prophet is deceived by another prophet, and slain by a lion.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 14
ch.desc: Ahias prophesieth the destruction of the family of Jeroboam.  He dieth, and is succeeded by his son Nadab.  The king of Egypt taketh and pillageth Jerusalem.  Roboam dieth and his son Abiam succeedeth.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 15
ch.desc: The acts of Abiam and of Asa kings of Juda.  And of Nadab and Baasa kings of Israel.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 16
ch.desc: Jehu prophesieth against Baasa:  his son Ela is slain and all his family destroyed by Zambri.  Of the reign of Amri father of Achab.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 17
ch.desc: Elias shutteth up the heaven from raining.  He is fed by ravens, and afterwards by a widow of Sarephta.  He raiseth the window's son to life.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 18
ch.desc: Elias cometh before Achab.  He convinceth the false prophets by bringing fire from heaven:  he obtaineth rain by his prayer.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 19
ch.desc: Elias, fleeing from Jezabel, is fed by an angel in the desert; and by the strength of that food walketh forty days, till he cometh to Horeb, where he hath a vision of God.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 20
ch.desc: The Syrians besiege Samaria:  they are twice defeated by Achab:  who is reprehended by a prophet for letting Benadad go.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 21
ch.desc: Naboth, for denying his vineyard to king Achab, is by Jezabel's commandment, falsely accused and stoned to death.  For which crime Elias denounceth to Achab the judgments of God:  upon his humbling himself the sentence is mitigated.

ch.name: 3 Kings Chapter 22
ch.desc: Achab believing his false prophets, rather than Micheas, is slain in Ramoth Galaad.  Ochozias succeedeth him.  Good king Josaphat dieth, and his son Joram succeedeth him.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 1
ch.desc: Ochozias sendeth to consult Beelzebub:  Elias foretelleth his death:  and causeth fire to come down from heaven, upon two captains and their companies.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 2
ch.desc: Eliseus will not part from Elias.  The water of the Jordan is divided by Elias' cloak.  Elias is taken up in a fiery chariot, and his double spirit is given to Eliseus.  Eliseus healeth the waters by casting in salt.  Boys are torn by bears for mocking Eliseus.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 3
ch.desc: The kings of Israel, Juda, and Edom, fight against the king of Moab. They want water, which Eliseus procureth without rain:  and prophesieth victory.  The king of Moab is overthrown, his city is besieged:  he sacrificeth his firstborn son:  so the Israelites raise the siege.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 4
ch.desc: Miracles of Eliseus.  He raiseth a dead child to life.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 5
ch.desc: Naaman the Syrian is cleansed of his leprosy.  He professeth his belief in one God, promising to serve him.  Giezi taketh gifts of Naaman, and is struck with leprosy.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 6
ch.desc: Eliseus maketh iron to swim upon the water:  he leadeth the Syrians that were sent to apprehend him into Samaria, where there eyes being opened, they are courteously entertained.  The Syrians besiege Samaria:  the famine there causeth a woman to eat her own child.  Upon this the king commandeth Eliseus to be put to death.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 7
ch.desc: Eliseus prophesieth a great plenty, which presently ensueth upon the sudden flight of the Syrians; of which four lepers bring the news to the city.  The incredulous nobleman is trod to death.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 8
ch.desc: After seven years' famine foretold by Eliseus, the Sunamitess returning home, recovereth her lands, and revenues.  Eliseus foresheweth the death of Benadad, king of Syria, and the reign of Hazael.  Joram's wicked reign in Juda.  He dieth, and his son Ochozias succeedeth.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 9
ch.desc: Jehu is anointed king of Israel, to destroy the house of Achab and Jezebel.  He killeth Joram king of Israel, and Ochozias king of Juda. Jezebel is eaten by dogs.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 10
ch.desc: Jehu destroyeth the house of Achab:  abolisheth the worship of Baal, and killeth the worshippers:  but sticketh to the calves of Jeroboam.  Israel is afflicted by the Syrians.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 11
ch.desc: Athalia's usurpation and tyranny.  Joas is made king.  Athalia is slain.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 12
ch.desc: The temple is repaired.  Hazael is bought off from attacking Jerusalem. Joas is slain.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 13
ch.desc: The reign of Joachaz and of Joas kings of Israel.  The last acts and death of Eliseus the prophet:  a dead man is raised to life by the touch of his bones.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 14
ch.desc: Amasias reigneth in Juda:  he overcometh the Edomites:  but is overcome by Joas king of Israel.  Jereboam the second reigneth in Israel.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 15
ch.desc: The reign of Azarias, and Joatham in Juda:  and of Zacharias, Sellum, Manahem, Phaceia, and Phacee in Israel.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 16
ch.desc: The wicked reign of Achaz:  the kings of Syria and Israel war against him:  he hireth the king of the Assyrians to assist him:  he causeth an altar to be made after the pattern of that of Damascus.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 17
ch.desc: The reign of Osee.  The Israelites for their sins are carried into captivity:  other inhabitants are sent to Samaria, who make a mixture of religion.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 18
ch.desc: The reign of Ezechias:  he abolisheth idolatry and prospereth. Sennacherib cometh up against him:  Rabsaces soliciteth the people to revolt; and blasphemeth the Lord.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 19
ch.desc: Ezechias is assured of God's help by Isaias the prophet.  The king of the Assyrians still threateneth and blasphemeth.  Ezechias prayeth, and God promiseth to protect Jerusalem.  An angel destroyeth the army of the Assyrians, their king returneth to Nineve, and is slain by his two sons.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 20
ch.desc: Ezechias being sick, is told by Isaias that he shall die; but praying to God, he obtaineth longer life, and in confirmation thereof receiveth a sign by the sun's returning back.  He sheweth all his treasures to the ambassadors of the king of Babylon:  Isaias reproving him for it, foretelleth the Babylonish captivity.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 21
ch.desc: The wickedness of Manasses:  God's threats by his prophets.  His wicked son Amon succeedeth him, and is slain by his servants.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 22
ch.desc: Josias repaireth the temple.  The book of the law is found, upon which they consult the Lord, and are told that great evils shall fall upon them, but not in the time of Josias.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 23
ch.desc: Josias readeth the law before all the people.  They promise to observe it.  He abolisheth all idolatry, celebrateth the phase:  is slain in battle by the king of Egypt.  The short reign of Joachaz, in whose place Joakim is made king.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 24
ch.desc: The reign of Joakim, Joachin, and Sedecias.

ch.name: 4 Kings Chapter 25
ch.desc: Jerusalem is besieged and taken by Nabuchodonosor:  Sedecias is taken: the city and temple are destroyed.  Godolias, who is left governor, is slain.  Joachin is exalted by Evilmerodach.

name: First Book of Paralipomenon
desc: These Books are called by the Greek interpreters, Paralipomenon, that is, of things left out, or omitted; because they are a kind of a supplement of such things as were passed over in the books of the Kings.  The Hebrews call them Dibre Haijamim, that is, The words of the days, or The Chronicles.--Not that they are the books which are so often quoted in the Kings, under the title of the words of the days of the kings of Israel, and of the kings of Juda:  for the books of Paralipomenon were written after the books of Kings:  but because in all probability they have been abridged from those ancient words of the days, by Esdras or some other sacred writer.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 1
ch.desc: The genealogy of the patriarchs down to Abraham:  The posterity of Abraham and of Esau.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 2
ch.desc: The twelve tribes of Israel.  The genealogy of Juda down to David.  Other genealogies of the tribe of Juda.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 3
ch.desc: The genealogy of the house of David.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 4
ch.desc: Other genealogies of Juda and Simeon, and their victories.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 5
ch.desc: Genealogies of Ruben and Gad:  their victories over the Agarites:  their captivity.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 6
ch.desc: The genealogies of Levi, and of Aaron:  the cities of the Levites.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 7
ch.desc: Genealogies of Issachar, Benjamin, Nephtali, Manasses, Ephraim, and Aser.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 8
ch.desc: The posterity of Benjamin is further declared down to Saul.  His issue.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 9
ch.desc: The Israelites, priests, and Levites, who first dwelt in Jerusalem after the captivity.  A repetition of the genealogy of Saul.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 10
ch.desc: Saul is slain for his sins:  he is buried by the men of Jabes.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 11
ch.desc: David is made king.  He taketh the castle of Sion.  A catalogue of his valiant men.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 12
ch.desc: Who followed David when he fled from Saul.  And who came to Hebron to make him king.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 13
ch.desc: The ark is brought from Cariathiarim.  Oza for touching it is struck dead.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 14
ch.desc: David's house, and children:  his victories over the Philistines.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 15
ch.desc: The ark is brought into the city of David, with great solemnity.  Michol derideth David's devotion.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 16
ch.desc: The ark is placed in the tabernacle.  Sacrifice is offered.  David blesseth the people, disposeth the offices of Levites, and maketh a psalm of praise to God.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 17
ch.desc: David's purpose to build a temple, is rewarded by most ample promises: David's thanksgiving.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 18
ch.desc: David's victories.  His chief officers.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 19
ch.desc: The Ammonites abuse David's ambassadors:  both they and their confederates are overthrown.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 20
ch.desc: Rabba is taken.  Other victories over the Philistines.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 21
ch.desc: David's sin in numbering the people is punished by a pestilence:  which ceaseth upon his offering sacrifice in the thrashingfloor of Ornan.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 22
ch.desc: David having prepared all necessaries, chargeth Solomon to build the temple and the princes to assist him.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 23
ch.desc: David appointeth Solomon king.  The distribution of the Levites and their offices.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 24
ch.desc: The divisions of the priests into four and twenty courses, to serve in the temple:  the chiefs of the Levites.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 25
ch.desc: The number and divisions of the musicians.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 26
ch.desc: The divisions of the porters.  Offices of other Levites.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 27
ch.desc: The twelve captains for every month; the twelve princes of the tribes. David's several officers.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 28
ch.desc: David's speech, in a solemn assembly:  his exhortation to Solomon.  He giveth him a pattern of the temple.

ch.name: 1 Paralipomenon Chapter 29
ch.desc: David by word and example encourageth the princes to contribute liberally to the building of the temple.  His thanksgiving, prayer, and sacrifices:  his death.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 1
ch.desc: Solomon offereth sacrifices at Gabaon.  His choice of wisdom which God giveth him.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 2
ch.desc: Solomon's embassy to Hiram, who sends him a skilful workman and timber.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 3
ch.desc: The plan and ornaments of the temple:  the cherubims, the veil, and the pillars.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 4
ch.desc: The altar of brass, the molten sea upon twelve oxen, the ten loaves, the candlesticks and other vessels and ornaments of the temple.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 5
ch.desc: The ark is brought with great solemnity into the temple:  the temple is filled with the glory of God.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 6
ch.desc: Solomon's blessings and prayer.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 7
ch.desc: Fire from heaven consumeth the sacrifices.  The solemnity of the dedication of the temple.  God signifieth his having heard Solomon's prayer:  yet so if he continue to serve him.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 8
ch.desc: Solomon's buildings and other acts.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 9
ch.desc: The queen of Saba admireth the wisdom of Solomon.  His riches and glory. His death.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 10
ch.desc: Roboam answereth the people roughly:  upon which ten tribes revolt.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 11
ch.desc: Roboam's reign.  His kingdom is strengthened.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 12
ch.desc: Roboam for his sins is delivered up into the hands of the king of Egypt:  who carrieth away all the treasures of the temple.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 13
ch.desc: Abia's reign:  his victory over Jeroboam.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 14
ch.desc: The reign of Asa:  his victory over the Ethiopians.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 15
ch.desc: The prophecy of Azarias.  Asa's covenant with God.  He deposeth his mother.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 16
ch.desc: Asa is reproved for seeking help from the Syrians:  his last acts and death.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 17
ch.desc: Josaphat's reign:  his care for the instruction of his people:  his numerous forces.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 18
ch.desc: Josaphat accompanies Achab in his expedition against Ramoth; where Achab is slain, as Micheas had foretold.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 19
ch.desc: Josaphat's charge to the judges and to the Levites.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 20
ch.desc: The Ammonites, Moabites, and Syrians combine against Josaphat:  he seeketh God's help by public prayer and fasting.  A prophet foretelleth that God will fight for his people:  the enemies destroy one another. Josaphat with his men gathereth the spoils.  He reigneth in peace, but his navy perisheth, for his society with wicked Ochozias.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 21
ch.desc: Joram's wicked reign:  his punishment and death.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 22
ch.desc: The reign and death of Ochozias.  The tyranny of Athalia.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 23
ch.desc: Joiada the high priest causeth Joas to be made king:  Athalia to be slain, and idolatry to be destroyed.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 24
ch.desc: Joas reigneth well all the days of Joiada:  afterwards falleth into idolatry and causeth Zacharias to be slain.  He is slain himself by his servants.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 25
ch.desc: Amasias' reign:  he beginneth well, but endeth ill:  he is overthrown by Joas, and slain by his people.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 26
ch.desc: Ozias reigneth prosperously, till he invadeth the priests' office, upon which he is struck with a leprosy.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 27
ch.desc: Joatham's good reign.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 28
ch.desc: The wicked and unhappy reign of Achaz.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 29
ch.desc: Ezechias purifieth the temple, and restoreth religion.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 30
ch.desc: Ezechias inviteth all Israel to celebrate the pasch; the solemnity is kept fourteen days.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 31
ch.desc: Idolatry is abolished; and provisions made for the ministers.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 32
ch.desc: Sennacherib invadeth Juda:  his army is destroyed by an angel.  Ezechias recovereth from his sickness:  his other acts.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 33
ch.desc: Manasses for his manifold wickedness is led captive to Babylon:  he repenteth, and is restored to his kingdom, and destroyeth idolatry:  his successor Amon is slain by his servants.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 34
ch.desc: Josias destroyeth idolatry, repaireth the temple, and reneweth the covenant between God and the people.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 35
ch.desc: Josias celebrateth a most solemn pasch.  He is slain by the king of Egypt.

ch.name: 2 Paralipomenon Chapter 36
ch.desc: The reigns of Joachaz, Joakim, Joachin, and Sedecias:  the captivity of Babylon released at length by Cyrus.

name: First Book of Esdras
desc: This Book taketh its name from the writer:  who was a holy priest, and doctor of the law.  He is called by the Hebrews, Ezra.

ch.name: 1 Esdras Chapter 1
ch.desc: Cyrus king of Persia releaseth God's people from their captivity, with license to return and build the temple in Jerusalem:  and restoreth the holy vessels which Nabuchodonosor had taken from thence.

ch.name: 1 Esdras Chapter 2
ch.desc: The number of them that returned to Judea:  their oblations.

ch.name: 1 Esdras Chapter 3
ch.desc: An altar is built for sacrifice, the feast of tabernacles is solemnly celebrated, and the foundations of the temple are laid.

ch.name: 1 Esdras Chapter 4
ch.desc: The Samaritans by their letter to the king hinder the building.

ch.name: 1 Esdras Chapter 5
ch.desc: By the exhortation of Aggeus, and Zacharias, the people proceed in building the temple.  Which their enemies strive in vain to hinder.

ch.name: 1 Esdras Chapter 6
ch.desc: King Darius favoureth the building and contributeth to it.

ch.name: 1 Esdras Chapter 7
ch.desc: Esdras goeth up to Jerusalem to teach, and assist the people, with a gracious decree of Artaxerxes.

ch.name: 1 Esdras Chapter 8
ch.desc: The companions of Esdras.  The fast which he appointed.  They bring the holy vessels into the temple.

ch.name: 1 Esdras Chapter 9
ch.desc: Esdras mourneth for the transgression of the people:  his confession and prayer.

ch.name: 1 Esdras Chapter 10
ch.desc: Order is given for discharging strange women:  the names of the guilty.

name: Book of Nehemias
fmlname: THE BOOK OF NEHEMIAS, WHICH IS CALLED THE SECOND OF ESDRAS
desc: This Book takes its name from the writer, who was cupbearer to Artaxerxes (surnamed Longimanus) king of Persia, and was sent by him with a commission to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem.  It is also called the second book of Esdras; because it is a continuation of the history, begun by Esdras, of the state of the people of God after their return from captivity.

ch.name: 2 Esdras Chapter 1
ch.desc: Nehemias hearing the miserable state of his countrymen in Judea, lamenteth, fasteth, and prayeth to God for their relief.

ch.name: 2 Esdras Chapter 2
ch.desc: Nehemias with commission from king Artaxerxes cometh to Jerusalem:  and exhorteth the Jews to rebuild the walls.

ch.name: 2 Esdras Chapter 3
ch.desc: They begin to build the walls:  the names and order of the builders.

ch.name: 2 Esdras Chapter 4
ch.desc: The building is carried on notwithstanding the opposition of their enemies.

ch.name: 2 Esdras Chapter 5
ch.desc: Nehemias blameth the rich, for their oppressing the poor.  His exhortation, and bounty to his countrymen.

ch.name: 2 Esdras Chapter 6
ch.desc: The enemies seek to terrify Nehemias.  He proceedeth and finisheth the wall.

ch.name: 2 Esdras Chapter 7
ch.desc: Nehemias appointeth watchmen in Jerusalem.  The list of those who came first from Babylon.

ch.name: 2 Esdras Chapter 8
ch.desc: Esdras readeth the law before the people.  Nehemias comforteth them. They celebrate the feast of tabernacles.

ch.name: 2 Esdras Chapter 9
ch.desc: The people repent with fasting and sackcloth.  The Levites confess God's benefits, and the people's ingratitude:  they pray for them, and make a covenant with God.

ch.name: 2 Esdras Chapter 10
ch.desc: The names of the subscribers to the covenant, and the contents of it.

ch.name: 2 Esdras Chapter 11
ch.desc: Who were the inhabitants of Jerusalem, and the other cities.

ch.name: 2 Esdras Chapter 12
ch.desc: The priests, and Levites that came up with Zorobabel.  The succession of high priests:  the solemnity of the dedication of the wall.

ch.name: 2 Esdras Chapter 13
ch.desc: Divers abuses are reformed.

name: Book of Tobias
desc: This Book takes its name from the holy man Tobias, whose wonderful virtues are herein recorded.  It contains most excellent documents of great piety, extraordinary patience, and of a perfect resignation to the will of God.  His humble prayer was heard, and the angel Raphael was sent to relieve him:  he is thankful and praises the Lord, calling on the children of Israel to do the same.  Having lived to the age of one hundred and two years, he exhorts his son and grandsons to piety, foretells the destruction of Ninive and the rebuilding of Jerusalem:  he dies happily.

ch.name: Tobias Chapter 1
ch.desc: Tobias's early piety:  his works of mercy, particularly in burying the dead.

ch.name: Tobias Chapter 2
ch.desc: Tobias leaveth his dinner to bury the dead:  he loseth his sight by God's permission, for manifestation of his patience.

ch.name: Tobias Chapter 3
ch.desc: The prayer of Tobias, and of Sara, in their several afflictions, are heard by God, and the angel Raphael is sent to relieve them.

ch.name: Tobias Chapter 4
ch.desc: Tobias thinking he shall die, giveth his son godly admonitions:  and telleth him of money he had lent to a friend.

ch.name: Tobias Chapter 5
ch.desc: Young Tobias seeking a guide for his journey, the angel Raphael, in shape of a man, undertaketh this office.

ch.name: Tobias Chapter 6
ch.desc: By the angel's advice young Tobias taketh hold on a fish that assaulteth him.  Reserveth the heart, the gall, and the liver for medicines.  They lodge at the house of Raguel, whose daughter Sara, Tobias is to marry; she had before been married to seven husbands, who were all slain by a devil.

ch.name: Tobias Chapter 7
ch.desc: They are kindly entertained by Raguel.  Tobias demandeth Sara to wife.

ch.name: Tobias Chapter 8
ch.desc: Tobias burneth part of the fish's liver, and Raphael bindeth the devil. Tobias and Sara pray.

ch.name: Tobias Chapter 9
ch.desc: The angel Raphael goeth to Gabelus, receiveth the money, and bringeth him to the marriage.

ch.name: Tobias Chapter 10
ch.desc: The parents lament the long absence of their son Tobias.  He sets out to return.

ch.name: Tobias Chapter 11
ch.desc: Tobias anointeth his father's eyes with the fish's gall, and he recovereth his sight.

ch.name: Tobias Chapter 12
ch.desc: Raphael maketh himself known.

ch.name: Tobias Chapter 13
ch.desc: Tobias the father praiseth God, exhorting all Israel to do the same. Prophesieth the restoration and better state of Jerusalem.

ch.name: Tobias Chapter 14
ch.desc: Old Tobias dieth at the age of a hundred and two years, after exhorting his son and grandsons to piety, foreshewing that Ninive shall be destroyed, and Jerusalem rebuilt.  The younger Tobias returneth with his family to Raguel, and dieth happily as he had lived.

name: Book of Judith
desc: The sacred writer of this Book is generally believed to be the high priest Eliachim (called also Joachim).  The transactions herein related, most probably happened in his days, and in the reign of Manasses, after his repentance and return from captivity.  It takes its name from that illustrious woman, by whose virtue and fortitude, and armed with prayer, the children of Israel were preserved from the destruction threatened them by Holofernes and his great army.  It finishes with her canticle of thanksgiving to God.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 1
ch.desc: Nabuchodonosor king of the Assyrians overcometh Arphaxad king of the Medes.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 2
ch.desc: Nabuchodonosor sendeth Holofernes to waste the countries of the west.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 3
ch.desc: Many submit themselves to Holofernes.  He destroyeth their cities, and their gods, that Nabuchodonosor only might be called God.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 4
ch.desc: The children of Israel prepare themselves to resist Holofernes.  They cry to the Lord for help.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 5
ch.desc: Achior gives Holofernes an account of the people of Israel.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 6
ch.desc: Holofernes in great rage sendeth Achior to Bethulia, there to be slain with the Israelites.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 7
ch.desc: Holofernes besiegeth Bethulia.  The distress of the besieged.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 8
ch.desc: The character of Judith:  her discourse to the ancients.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 9
ch.desc: Judith's prayer, to beg of God to fortify her in her undertaking.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 10
ch.desc: Judith goeth out towards the camp, and is taken, and brought to Holofernes.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 11
ch.desc: Judith's speech to Holofernes.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 12
ch.desc: Judith goeth out in the night to pray:  she is invited to a banquet with Holofernes.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 13
ch.desc: Judith cutteth off the head of Holofernes, and returneth to Bethulia.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 14
ch.desc: The Israelites assault the Assyrians, who finding their general slain, are seized with a panic fear.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 15
ch.desc: The Assyrians flee:  the Hebrews pursue after them, and are enriched by their spoils.

ch.name: Judith Chapter 16
ch.desc: The canticle of Judith:  her virtuous life and death.

name: Book of Esther
desc: This Book takes its name from queen Esther, whose history is here recorded.  The general opinion of almost all commentators on the Holy Scriptures makes Mardochai the writer of it:  which also may be collected below from chap. 9 ver. 20.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 1
ch.desc: King Assuerus maketh a great feast.  Queen Vasthi being sent for refuseth to come:  for which disobedience she is deposed.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 2
ch.desc: Esther is advanced to be queen.  Mardochai detecteth a plot against the king.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 3
ch.desc: Aman, advanced by the king, is offended at Mardochai, and therefore procureth the king's decree to destroy the whole nation of the Jews.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 4
ch.desc: Mardochai desireth Esther to petition the king for the Jews.  They join in fasting and prayer.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 5
ch.desc: Esther is graciously received:  she inviteth the king and Aman to dinner, Aman prepareth a gibbet for Mardochai.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 6
ch.desc: The king hearing of the good service done him by Mardochai, commandeth Aman to honour him next to the king, which he performeth.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 7
ch.desc: Esther's petition for herself and her people:  Aman is hanged upon the gibbet he had prepared for Mardochai.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 8
ch.desc: Mardochai is advanced:  Aman's letters are reversed.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 9
ch.desc: The Jews kill their enemies that would have killed them.  The days of Phurim are appointed to be kept holy.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 10
ch.desc: Assuerus's greatness.  Mardochai's dignity.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 11
ch.desc: The dream of Mardochai, which in the ancient Greek and Latin Bibles was into the beginning of the book, but was detached by St. Jerome, and put in this place.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 12
ch.desc: Mardochai detects the conspiracy of the two eunuchs.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 13
ch.desc: A copy of a letter sent by Aman to destroy the Jews.  Mardochai's prayer for the people.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 14
ch.desc: The prayer of Esther for herself and her people.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 15
ch.desc: Esther comes into the king's presence:  she is terrified, but God turns his heart.

ch.name: Esther Chapter 16
ch.desc: A copy of the king's letter in favour of the Jews.

name: Book of Job
desc: This Book takes its name from the holy man of whom it treats:  who, according to the more probable opinion, was of the race of Esau; and the same as Jobab, king of Edom, mentioned Gen. 36.33.  It is uncertain who was the writer of it.  Some attribute it to Job himself; others to Moses, or some one of the prophets.  In the Hebrew it is written in verse, from the beginning of the third chapter to the forty-second chapter.

ch.name: Job Chapter 1
ch.desc: Job's virtue and riches.  Satan by permission from God strippeth him of all his substance.  His patience.

ch.name: Job Chapter 11
ch.desc: Sophar reproves Job, for justifying himself, and invites him to repentance.

ch.name: Job Chapter 12
ch.desc: Job's reply to Sophar.  He extols God's power and wisdom.

ch.name: Job Chapter 13
ch.desc: Job persists in maintaining his innocence:  and reproves his friends.
