ch.name: Job Chapter 14
ch.desc: Job declares the shortness of man's days:  and professes his belief of a resurrection.

ch.name: Job Chapter 15
ch.desc: Eliphaz returns to the charge against Job, and describes the wretched state of the wicked.

ch.name: Job Chapter 16
ch.desc: Job expostulates with his friends:  and appeals to the judgment of God.

ch.name: Job Chapter 17
ch.desc: Job's hope in God:  he expects rest in death.

ch.name: Job Chapter 18
ch.desc: Baldad again reproves Job and describes the miseries of the wicked.

ch.name: Job Chapter 19
ch.desc: Job complains of the cruelty of his friends; he describes his own sufferings:  and his belief of a future resurrection.

ch.name: Job Chapter 20
ch.desc: Sophar declares the shortness of the prosperity of the wicked:  and their sudden downfall.

ch.name: Job Chapter 21
ch.desc: Job shews that the wicked often prosper in this world, even to the end of their life:  but that their judgment is in another world.

ch.name: Job Chapter 22
ch.desc: Eliphaz falsely imputes many crimes to Job, but promises him prosperity if he will repent.

ch.name: Job Chapter 23
ch.desc: Job wishes to be tried at God's tribunal.

ch.name: Job Chapter 24
ch.desc: God's providence often suffers the wicked to go on a long time in their sins:  but punisheth them in another life.

ch.name: Job Chapter 25
ch.desc: God's providence often suffers the wicked to go on a long time in their sins:  but punisheth them in another life.

ch.name: Job Chapter 26
ch.desc: Job declares his sentiments of the wisdom and power of God.

ch.name: Job Chapter 27
ch.desc: Job persists in asserting his own innocence, and that hypocrites will be punished in the end.

ch.name: Job Chapter 28
ch.desc: Man's industry searcheth out many things:  true wisdom is taught by God alone.

ch.name: Job Chapter 29
ch.desc: Job relates his former happiness, and the respect that all men shewed him.

ch.name: Job Chapter 30
ch.desc: Job shews the wonderful change of his temporal estate, from welfare to great calamity.

ch.name: Job Chapter 31
ch.desc: Job, to defend himself from the unjust judgments of his friends, gives a sincere account of his own virtues.

ch.name: Job Chapter 32
ch.desc: Eliu is angry with Job and his friends.  He boasts of himself.

ch.name: Job Chapter 33
ch.desc: Eliu blames Job for asserting his own innocence.

ch.name: Job Chapter 34
ch.desc: Eliu charges Job with blasphemy:  and sets forth the power and justice of God.

ch.name: Job Chapter 35
ch.desc: Eliu declares that the good or evil done by man cannot reach God.

ch.name: Job Chapter 36
ch.desc: Eliu proceeds in setting forth the justice and power of God.

ch.name: Job Chapter 37
ch.desc: Eliu goes on in his discourse, shewing God's wisdom and power, by his wonderful works.

ch.name: Job Chapter 38
ch.desc: God interposes and shews from the things he hath made, that man cannot comprehend his power and wisdom.

ch.name: Job Chapter 39
ch.desc: The wonders of the power and providence of God in many of his creatures.

ch.name: Job Chapter 40
ch.desc: Of the power of God in the behemoth and the leviathan.

ch.name: Job Chapter 41
ch.desc: A further description of the leviathan.

ch.name: Job Chapter 42
ch.desc: Job submits himself.  God pronounces in his favour.  Job offers sacrifice for his friends.  He is blessed with riches and children, and dies happily,

name: Book of Psalms
desc: The psalms are called by the Hebrews TEHILLIM, that is, Hymns of Praise.  The author, of a great part of them at least, was king David: but many are of opinion that some of them were made by Asaph, and others whose names are prefixed in the titles.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 1
ch.desc: Beatus vir. The happiness of the just and the evil state of the wicked.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 2
ch.desc: Quare fremuerunt. The vain efforts of persecutors against Christ and his church.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 3
ch.desc: Domine, quid multiplicati. The prophet's danger and delivery from his son Absalom:  mystically, the passion and resurrection of Christ.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 4
ch.desc: Cum invocarem. The prophet teacheth us to flee to God in tribulation, with confidence in him.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 5
ch.desc: Verba mea auribul. A prayer to God against the iniquities of men.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 6
ch.desc: Domine, ne in furore. A prayer of a penitent sinner, under the scourge of God.  The first penitential psalm.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 7
ch.desc: Domine, Deus meus. David, trusting in the justice of his cause, prayeth for God's help against his enemies.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 8
ch.desc: Domine, Dominus noster. God is wonderful in his works; especially in mankind, singularly exalted by the incarnation of Christ.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 9
ch.desc: Confitebor tibi, Domine.  The church praiseth God for his protection against her enemies.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 10
ch.desc: In Domino confido. The just man's confidence in God in the midst of persecutions.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 11
ch.desc: Salvum me fac. The prophet calls for God's help against the wicked.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 12
ch.desc: Usquequo, Domine. A prayer in tribulation.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 13
ch.desc: Dixit insipiens. The general corruption of man before our redemption by Christ.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 14
ch.desc: Domine, quis habitabit. What kind of men shall dwell in the heavenly Sion.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 15
ch.desc: Conserva me, Domine. Christ's future victory and triumph over the world and death.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 16
ch.desc: Exaudi, Domine, justitiam. A just man's prayer in tribulation against the malice of his enemy.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 17
ch.desc: Diligam te, Domine. David's thanks to God for his delivery from all his enemies.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 18
ch.desc: Coeli enarrant. The works of God shew forth his glory:  his law is greatly to be esteemed and loved.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 19
ch.desc: Exaudiat te Dominus. A prayer for the king.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 20
ch.desc: Domine, in virtute. Praise to God for Christ's exaltation after his passion.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 21
ch.desc: Deus Deus meus. Christ's passion:  and the conversion of the Gentiles.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 22
ch.desc: Dominus regit me. God's spiritual benefits to faithful souls.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 23
ch.desc: Domini est terra. Who are they that shall ascend to heaven:  Christ's triumphant ascension thither.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 24
ch.desc: Ad te, Domine, levavi. A prayer for grace, mercy, and protection against our enemies.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 25
ch.desc: Judica me, Domine. David's prayer to God in his distress, to be delivered, that he may come to worship him in his tabernacle.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 26
ch.desc: Dominus illuminatio. David's faith and hope in God.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 27
ch.desc: Ad te, Domine, clamabo. David's prayer that his enemies may not prevail over him.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 28
ch.desc: Afferte Domino. An invitation to glorify God, with a commemoration of his mighty works.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 29
ch.desc: Exaltabo te, Domine. David praiseth God for his deliverance, and his merciful dealings with him.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 30
ch.desc: In te, Domine, speravi. A prayer of a just man under affliction.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 31
ch.desc: Beati quorum. The second penitential psalm.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 32
ch.desc: Exultate, justi. An exhortation to praise God, and to trust in him.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 33
ch.desc: Benedicam Dominum. An exhortation to the praise, and service of God.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 34
ch.desc: Judica, Domine, nocentes me. David, in the person of Christ, prayeth against his persecutors: prophetically foreshewing the punishments that shall fall upon them.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 35
ch.desc: Dixit injustus. The malice of sinners, and the goodness of God.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 36
ch.desc: Noli aemulari. An exhortation to despise this world; and the short prosperity of the wicked; and to trust in Providence.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 37
ch.desc: Domine, ne in furore. A prayer of a penitent for the remission of his sins.  The third penitential psalm.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 38
ch.desc: Dixi custodiam. A just man's peace and patience in his sufferings; considering the vanity of the world, and the providence of God.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 39
ch.desc: Expectans expectavi. Christ's coming, and redeeming mankind.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 40
ch.desc: Beatus qui intelligit. The happiness of him that shall believe in Christ; notwithstanding the humility and poverty in which he shall come:  the malice of his enemies, especially of the traitor Judas.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 41
ch.desc: Quemadmodum desiderat. The fervent desire of the just after God:  hope in afflictions.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 42
ch.desc: Judica me, Deus. The prophet aspireth after the temple and altar of God.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 43
ch.desc: Deus auribus nostris. The church commemorates former favours, and present afflictions; under which she prays for succour.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 44
ch.desc: Eructavit cor meum. The excellence of Christ's kingdom, and the endowments of his church.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 45
ch.desc: Deus noster refugium. The church in persecution trusteth in the protection of God.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 46
ch.desc: Omnes gentes, plaudite. The Gentiles are invited to praise God for the establishment of the kingdom of Christ.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 47
ch.desc: Magnus Dominus. God is greatly to be praised for the establishment of his church.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 48
ch.desc: Audite haec, omnes gentes. The folly of worldlings, who live on in sin, without thinking of death or hell.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 49
ch.desc: Deus deorum. The coming of Christ:  who prefers virtue and inward purity before the blood of victims.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 50
ch.desc: Miserere. The repentance and confession of David after his sin.  The fourth penitential psalm.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 51
ch.desc: Quid gloriaris. David condemneth the wickedness of Doeg, and foretelleth his destruction.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 52
ch.desc: Dixit insipiens. The general corruption of man before the coming of Christ.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 53
ch.desc: Deus, in nomine tuo. A prayer for help in distress.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 54
ch.desc: Exaudi, Deus. A prayer of a just man under persecution from the wicked.  It agrees to Christ persecuted by the Jews, and betrayed by Judas.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 55
ch.desc: Miserere mei, Deus. A prayer of David in danger and distress.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 56
ch.desc: Miserere mei, Deus.  The prophet prays in his affliction, and praises God for his delivery.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 57
ch.desc: Si vere utique. David reproveth the wicked, and foretelleth their punishment.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 58
ch.desc: Eripe me. A prayer to be delivered from the wicked, with confidence in God's help and protection.  It agrees to Christ and his enemies the Jews.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 59
ch.desc: Deus, repulisti nos. After many afflictions, the church of Christ shall prevail.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 60
ch.desc: Exaudi, Deus. A prayer for the coming of the kingdom of Christ, which shall have no end.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 61
ch.desc: Nonne Deo. The prophet encourageth himself and all others to trust in God, and serve him.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 62
ch.desc: Deus Deus meus, ad te. The prophet aspireth after God.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 63
ch.desc: Exaudi Deus orationem. A prayer in affliction, with confidence in God that he will bring to nought the machinations of persecutors.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 64
ch.desc: Te decet. God is to be praised in his church, to which all nations shall be called.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 65
ch.desc: Jubilate Deo. An invitation to praise God.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 66
ch.desc: Deus misereatur. A prayer for the propagation of the church.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 67
ch.desc: Exurgat Deus. The glorious establishment of the church of the New Testament, prefigured by the benefits bestowed on the people of Israel.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 68
ch.desc: Salvum me fac, Deus. Christ in his passion declareth the greatness of his sufferings, and the malice of his persecutors the Jews; and foretelleth their reprobation.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 69
ch.desc: Deus in adjutorium. A prayer in persecution.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 70
ch.desc: In te, Domine. A prayer for perseverance.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 71
ch.desc: Deus, judicium tuum. A prophecy of the coming of Christ, and of his kingdom:  prefigured by Solomon and his happy reign.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 72
ch.desc: Quam bonus Israel Deus. The temptation of the weak, upon seeing the prosperity of the wicked, is overcome by the consideration of the justice of God, who will quickly render to every one according to his works.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 73
ch.desc: Ut quid, Deus. A prayer of the church under grievous persecutions.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 74
ch.desc: Confitebimur tibi. There is a just judgment to come:  therefore let the wicked take care.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 75
ch.desc: Notus in Judaea. God is known in his church:  and exerts his power in protecting it.  It alludes to the slaughter of the Assyrians, in the days of king Ezechias.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 76
ch.desc: Voce mea. The faithful have recourse to God in trouble of mind, with confidence in his mercy and power.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 77
ch.desc: Attendite. God's great benefits to the people of Israel, notwithstanding their ingratitude.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 78
ch.desc: Deus, venerunt gentes. The church in time of persecution prayeth for relief.  It seems to belong to the time of the Machabees.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 79
ch.desc: Qui regis Israel. A prayer for the church in tribulation, commemorating God's former favours.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 80
ch.desc: Exultate Deo. An invitation to a solemn praising of God.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 81
ch.desc: Deus stetit. An exhortation to judges and men in power.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 82
ch.desc: Deus, quis similis. A prayer against the enemies of God's church.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 83
ch.desc: Quam dilecta. The soul aspireth after heaven; rejoicing in the mean time, in being in the communion of God's church upon earth.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 84
ch.desc: Benedixisti, Domine. The coming of Christ, to bring peace and salvation to man.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 85
ch.desc: Inclina, Domine. A prayer for God's grace to assist us to the end.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 86
ch.desc: Fundamenta ejus. The glory of the church of Christ.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 87
ch.desc: Domine, Deus salutis. A prayer of one under grievous affliction:  it agrees to Christ in his passion, and alludes to his death and burial.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 88
ch.desc: Misericordias Domini. The perpetuity of the church of Christ, in consequence of the promise of God:  which, notwithstanding, God permits her to suffer sometimes most grievous afflictions.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 89
ch.desc: Domine, refugium. A prayer for the mercy of God:  recounting the shortness and miseries of the days of man.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 90
ch.desc: Qui habitat. The just is secure under the protection of God.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 91
ch.desc: Bonum est confiteri. God is to be praised for his wondrous works.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 92
ch.desc: Dominus regnavit. The glory and stability of the kingdom; that is, of the church of Christ. Praise in the way of a canticle, for David himself, on the day before the sabbath, when the earth was founded.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 93
ch.desc: Deus ultionum. God shall judge and punish the oppressors of his people. A psalm for David himself on the fourth day of the week.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 94
ch.desc: Venite exultemus. An invitation to adore and serve God, and to hear his voice. Praise of a canticle for David himself.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 95
ch.desc: Cantate Domino. An exhortation to praise God for the coming of Christ and his kingdom.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 96
ch.desc: Dominus regnavit. All are invited to rejoice at the glorious coming and reign of Christ.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 97
ch.desc: Cantate Domino. All are again invited to praise the Lord, for the victories of Christ.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 98
ch.desc: Dominus regnavit. The reign of the Lord in Sion:  that is, of Christ in his church.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 99
ch.desc: Jubilate Deo. All are invited to rejoice in God the creator of all.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 100
ch.desc: Misericordiam et judicium. The prophet exhorteth all by his example, to follow mercy and justice.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 101
ch.desc: Domine, exaudi. A prayer for one in affliction:  the fifth penitential psalm.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 102
ch.desc: Benedic, anima. Thanksgiving to God for his mercies.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 103
ch.desc: Benedic, anima. God is to be praised for his mighty works, and wonderful providence.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 104
ch.desc: Confitemini Domino. A thanksgiving to God for his benefits to his people Israel. Alleluia.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 105
ch.desc: Confitemini Domino. A confession of the manifold sins and ingratitudes of the Israelites. Alleluia.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 106
ch.desc: Confitemini Domino. All are invited to give thanks to God for his perpetual providence over men. Alleluia.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 107
ch.desc: Paratum cor meum. The prophet praiseth God for benefits received.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 108
ch.desc: Deus, laudem meam. David in the person of Christ, prayeth against his persecutors; more especially the traitor Judas:  foretelling and approving his just punishment for his obstinacy in sin and final impenitence.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 109
ch.desc: Dixit Dominus. Christ's exaltation and everlasting priesthood.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 110
ch.desc: Confitebor tibi, Domine. God is to be praised for his graces, and benefits to his church. Alleluia.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 111
ch.desc: Beatus vir. The good man is happy. Alleluia, of the returning of Aggeus and Zacharias.
ch.chapternotes: Of the returning, etc. . .This is in the Greek and Latin, but not in the Hebrew.  It signifies that this psalm was proper to be sung at the time of the return of the people from their captivity; to inculcate to them, how happy they might be, if they would be constant in the service of God.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 112
ch.desc: Laudate, pueri. God is to be praised for his regard to the poor and humble. Alleluia.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 113
ch.desc: In exitu Israel. God hath shewn his power in delivering his people:  idols are vain.  The Hebrews divide this into two psalms. Alleluia.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 114
ch.desc: Dilexi. The prayer of a just man in affliction, with a lively confidence in God. Alleluia.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 115
ch.desc: Credidi. This in the Hebrew is joined with the foregoing psalm, and continues to express the faith and gratitude of the psalmist. Alleluia.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 116
ch.desc: Laudate Dominum. All nations are called upon to praise God for his mercy and truth. Alleluia.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 117
ch.desc: Confitemini Domino. The psalmist praiseth God for his delivery from evils:  putteth his whole trust in him; and foretelleth the coming of Christ. Alleluia.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 118
ch.desc: Beati immaculati. Of the excellence of virtue consisting in the love and observance of the commandments of God. Alleluia. ALEPH.
ch.chapternotes: Aleph. . .The first eight verses of this psalm in the original begin with Aleph, which is the name of the first letter of the Hebrew alphabet.  The second eight verses begin with Beth, the name of the second letter of the Hebrew alphabet; and so to the end of the whole alphabet, in all twenty-two letters, each letter having eight verses. This order is variously expounded by the holy fathers; which shews the difficulty of understanding the holy scriptures, and consequently with what humility, and submission to the Church they are to be read.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 119
ch.desc: Ad Dominum. A prayer in tribulation. A gradual canticle.
ch.chapternotes: A gradual canticle. . .The following psalms, in number fifteen, are called gradual psalms, or canticles, from the word gradus, signifying steps, ascensions, or degrees:  either because they were appointed to be sung on the fifteen steps, by which the people ascended to the temple: or, that in the singing of them the voice was to be raised by certain steps or ascensions:  or, that they were to be sung by the people returning from their captivity and ascending to Jerusalem, which was seated amongst mountains.  The holy fathers, in a mystical sense, understand these steps, or ascensions, of the degrees by which Christians spiritually ascend to virtue and perfection; and to the true temple of God in the heavenly Jerusalem.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 120
ch.desc: Levavi oculos. God is the keeper of his servants. A gradual canticle.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 121
ch.desc: Laetatus sum in his. The desire and hope of the just for the coming of the kingdom of God, and the peace of his church.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 122
ch.desc: Ad te levavi. A prayer in affliction, with confidence in God. A gradual canticle.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 123
ch.desc: Nisi quia Domini. The church giveth glory to God for her deliverance, from the hands of her enemies.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 124
ch.desc: Qui confidunt. The just are always under God's protection.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 125
ch.desc: In convertendo. The people of God rejoice at their delivery from captivity.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 126
ch.desc: Nisi Dominus. Nothing can be done without God's grace and blessing.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 127
ch.desc: Beati omnes. The fear of God is the way to happiness.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 128
ch.desc: Saepe expugnaverunt. The church of God is invincible :  her persecutors come to nothing.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 129
ch.desc: De profundis. A prayer of a sinner, trusting in the mercies of God.  The sixth penitential psalm.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 130
ch.desc: Domine, none est. The prophet's humility.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 131
ch.desc: Memento, Domine. A prayer for the fulfilling of the promise made to David.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 132
ch.desc: Ecce quam bonum. The happiness of brotherly love and concord.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 133
ch.desc: Ecce nunc benedicite. An exhortation to praise God continually.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 134
ch.desc: Laudate nomen. An exhortation to praise God:  the vanity of idols.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 135
ch.desc: Confitemini Domino. God is to be praised for his wonderful works.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 136
ch.desc: Super flumina. The lamentation of the people of God in their captivity in Babylon. A psalm of David, for Jeremias.
ch.chapternotes: For Jeremias. . .For the time of Jeremias, and the captivity of Babylon.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 137
ch.desc: Confitebor tibi. Thanksgiving to God for his benefits.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 138
ch.desc: Domine, probasti. God's special providence over his servants.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 139
ch.desc: Eripe me, Domine. A prayer to be delivered from the wicked.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 140
ch.desc: Domine, clamavi. A prayer against sinful words, and deceitful flatterers. A psalm of David.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 141
ch.desc: Voce mea. A prayer of David in extremity of danger.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 142
ch.desc: Domine, exaudi. The psalmist in tribulation calleth upon God for his delivery.  The seventh penitential psalm.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 143
ch.desc: Benedictus Dominus. The prophet praiseth God, and prayeth to be delivered from his enemies. No worldly happiness is to be compared with that of serving God. A psalm of David against Goliath.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 144
ch.desc: Exaltabo te, Deus. A psalm of praise, to the infinite majesty of God.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 145
ch.desc: Lauda, anima. We are not to trust in men, but in God alone.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 146
ch.desc: Laudate Dominum. An exhortation to praise God for his benefits.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 147
ch.desc: Lauda, Jerusalem. The church is called upon to praise God for his peculiar graces and favours to his people.  In the Hebrew, this psalm is joined to the foregoing. Alleluia.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 148
ch.desc: Laudate Dominum de caelis. All creatures are invited to praise their Creator. Alleluia.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 149
ch.desc: Cantate Domino. The church is particularly bound to praise God. Alleluia.

ch.name: Psalms Chapter 150
ch.desc: Laudate Dominum in sanctis. An exhortation to praise God with all sorts of instruments. Alleluia.

name: Book of Proverbs
desc: This Book is so called, because it consists of wise and weighty sentences:  regulating the morals of men:  and directing them to wisdom and virtue.  And these sentences are also called PARABLES, because great truths are often couched in them under certain figures and similitudes.

ch.name: Proverbs Chapter 1
ch.desc: The use and end of the proverbs.  An exhortation to flee the company of the wicked:  and to hearken to the voice of wisdom.

ch.name: Proverbs Chapter 2
ch.desc: The advantages of wisdom:  and the evils from which it delivers.

ch.name: Proverbs Chapter 3
ch.desc: An exhortation to the practice of virtue.

ch.name: Proverbs Chapter 4
ch.desc: A further exhortation to seek after wisdom.

ch.name: Proverbs Chapter 5
ch.desc: An exhortation to fly unlawful lust, and the occasions of it.

ch.name: Proverbs Chapter 6
ch.desc: Documents on several heads.

ch.name: Proverbs Chapter 7
ch.desc: The love of wisdom is the best preservative from being led astray by temptation.

ch.name: Proverbs Chapter 8
ch.desc: The preaching of wisdom.  Her excellence.

ch.name: Proverbs Chapter 9
ch.desc: Wisdom invites all to her feast.  Folly calls another way.

ch.name: Proverbs Chapter 10
ch.desc: In the twenty following ch are contained many wise sayings and axioms, relating to wisdom and folly, virtue and vice.

ch.name: Proverbs Chapter 30
ch.desc: The wise man thinketh humbly of himself.  His prayer and sentiments upon certain virtues and vices.

ch.name: Proverbs Chapter 31
ch.desc: An exhortation to chastity, temperance, and works of mercy; with the praise of a wise woman.

name: Ecclesiastes
desc: This Book is called Ecclesiastes, or The Preacher, (in Hebrew, Coheleth,) because in it, Solomon, as an excellent preacher, setteth forth the vanity of the things of this world:  to withdraw the hearts and affections of men from such empty toys.

ch.name: Ecclesiastes Chapter 1
ch.desc: The vanity of all temporal things.

ch.name: Ecclesiastes Chapter 2
ch.desc: The vanity of pleasures, riches, and worldly labours.

ch.name: Ecclesiastes Chapter 3
ch.desc: All human things are liable to perpetual changes.  We are to rest on God's providence, and cast away fruitless cares.

ch.name: Ecclesiastes Chapter 4
ch.desc: Other instances of human miseries.

ch.name: Ecclesiastes Chapter 5
ch.desc: Caution in words.  Vows are to be paid.  Riches are often pernicious: the moderate use of them is the gift of God.

ch.name: Ecclesiastes Chapter 6
ch.desc: The misery of the covetous man.

ch.name: Ecclesiastes Chapter 7
ch.desc: Prescriptions against worldly vanities:  mortification, patience, and seeking wisdom.

ch.name: Ecclesiastes Chapter 8
ch.desc: True wisdom is to observe God's commandments.  The ways of God are unsearchable.

ch.name: Ecclesiastes Chapter 9
ch.desc: Man knows not certainty that he is in God's grace.  After death no more work or merit.

ch.name: Ecclesiastes Chapter 10
ch.desc: Observations on wisdom and folly, ambition and detraction.

ch.name: Ecclesiastes Chapter 11
ch.desc: Exhortation to works of mercy, while we have time, to diligence in good, and to the remembrance of death and judgment.

ch.name: Ecclesiastes Chapter 12
ch.desc: The Creator is to be remembered in the days of our youth:  all worldly things are vain:  we should fear God and keep his commandments.

name: Solomon's Canticle of Canticles
desc: This Book is called the Canticle of Canticles, that is to say, the most excellent of all canticles:  because it is full of high mysteries, relating to the happy union of Christ and his spouse:  which is here begun by love; and is to be eternal in heaven.  The spouse of Christ is the church:  more especially as to the happiest part of it, viz., perfect souls, every one of which is his beloved, but, above all others, the immaculate and ever blessed virgin mother.

ch.name: Canticle of Canticles Chapter 1
ch.desc: The spouse aspires to an union with Christ, their mutual love for one another.

ch.name: Canticle of Canticles Chapter 2
ch.desc: Christ caresses his spouse:  he invites her to him.

ch.name: Canticle of Canticles Chapter 3
ch.desc: The spouse seeks Christ.  The glory of his humanity.

ch.name: Canticle of Canticles Chapter 4
ch.desc: Christ sets forth the graces of his spouse:  and declares his love for her.

ch.name: Canticle of Canticles Chapter 5
ch.desc: Christ calls his spouse:  she languishes with love:  and describes him by his graces.

ch.name: Canticle of Canticles Chapter 6
ch.desc: The spouse of Christ is but one:  she is fair and terrible.

ch.name: Canticle of Canticles Chapter 7

name: Book of Wisdom
desc: This Book is so called, because it treats of the excellence of WISDOM, the means to obtain it, and the happy fruits it produces.  It is written in the person of Solomon, and contains his sentiments.  But it is uncertain who was the writer.  It abounds with instructions and exhortations to kings and all magistrates to minister justice in the commonwealth, teaching all kinds of virtues under the general names of justice and wisdom.  It contains also many prophecies of Christ's coming, passion, resurrection, and other Christian mysteries.  The whole may be divided into three parts.  In the first six ch, the author admonishes all superiors to love and exercise justice and wisdom.  In the next three, he teacheth that wisdom proceedeth only from God, and is procured by prayer and a good life.  In the other ten ch, he sheweth the excellent effects and utility of wisdom and justice.

ch.name: Wisdom Chapter 1

name: Ecclesiasticus
desc: This Book is so called from a Greek word that signifies a preacher: because, like an excellent preacher, it gives admirable lessons of all virtues.  The author was Jesus the son of Sirach of Jerusalem, who flourished about two hundred years before Christ.  As it was written after the time of Esdras, it is not in the Jewish canon; but is received as canonical and divine by the Catholic Church, instructed by apostolical tradition, and directed by the spirit of God.  It was first written in the Hebrew, but afterwards translated into Greek, by another Jesus, the grandson of the author, whose prologue to this book is the following: THE PROLOGUE. The knowledge of many and great things hath been shewn us by the law, and the prophets, and others that have followed them:  for which things Israel is to be commended for doctrine and wisdom, because not only they that speak must needs be skilful, but strangers also, both speaking and writing, may by their means become most learned.  My grandfather Jesus, after he had much given himself to a diligent reading of the law, and the prophets, and other books, that were delivered to us from our fathers, had a mind also to write something himself, pertaining to doctrine and wisdom; that such as are desirous to learn, and are made knowing in these things, may be more and more attentive in mind, and be strengthened to live according to the law.  I entreat you therefore to come with benevolence, and to read with attention, and to pardon us for those things wherein we may seem, while we follow the image of wisdom, to come short in the composition of words; for the Hebrew words have not the same force in them when translated into another tongue.  And not only these, but the law also itself, and the prophets, and the rest of the books, have no small difference, when they are spoken in their own language.  For in the eight and thirtieth year coming into Egypt, when Ptolemy Evergetes was king, and continuing there a long time, I found there books left, of no small nor contemptible learning.  Therefore I thought it good, and necessary for me to bestow some diligence and labour to interpret this book; and with much watching and study in some space of time, I brought the book to an end, and set it forth for the service of them that are willing to apply their mind, and to learn how they ought to conduct themselves, who purpose to lead their life according to the law of the Lord.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 3
ch.desc: Lessons concerning the honour of parents, and humility, and avoiding curiosity.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 4
ch.desc: An exhortation to works of mercy, and to the love of wisdom.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 5
ch.desc: We must not presume of our wealth or strength:  nor of the mercy of God, to go on in sin:  we must be steadfast in virtue and truth.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 6
ch.desc: Of true and false friends:  and of the of the fruits of wisdom.

ch.desc: Religious and moral duties.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 8
ch.desc: Other lessons of wisdom and virtue.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 9
ch.desc: Cautions with regard to women, and dangerous conversations.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 10
ch.desc: The virtues and vices of men in power:  the great evil of pride.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 11
ch.desc: Lessons of humility and moderation in all things.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 12
ch.desc: We are to be liberal to the just:  and not to trust the wicked.

ch.desc: Cautions in the choice of company.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 14
ch.desc: The evil of avarice:  works of mercy are recommended, and the love of wisdom.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 15
ch.desc: Wisdom embraceth them that fear God.  God is not the author of sin.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 17
ch.desc: The creation and favour of God to man.  An exhortation to turn to God.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 18
ch.desc: God's works are wonderful:  we must serve him, and not our lusts.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 19
ch.desc: Admonition against sundry vices.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 20
ch.desc: Rules with regard to correction, discretion, and avoiding lies.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 21
ch.desc: Cautions against sin in general, and some sins in particular.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 22
ch.desc: Wise sayings on divers subjects.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 23
ch.desc: A prayer for grace to flee sin:  cautions against profane swearing and other vices.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 24
ch.desc: Wisdom praiseth herself:  her origin, her dwelling, her dignity, and her fruits.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 25
ch.desc: Documents of wisdom on several subjects.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 26
ch.desc: Of good and bad women.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 27
ch.desc: Dangers of sin from several heads:  the fear of God is the best preservative.  He that diggeth a pit, shall fall into it.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 28
ch.desc: Lessons against revenge and quarrels.  The evils of the tongue.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 29

ch.desc: Of the desire of riches, and of moderation in eating and drinking.

ch.desc: What sacrifices are pleasing to God.

ch.desc: A prayer for the church of God.  Of a good heart, and a good wife.

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 37

ch.name: Ecclesiasticus Chapter 38

ch.desc: The praise of Josue, of Caleb, and of Samuel.

name: Prophecy of Isaias
desc: This inspired writer is called by the Holy Ghost, the great prophet, (Ecclesiasticus 48.25,) from the greatness of his prophetic spirit, by which he hath foretold so long before, and in so clear a manner, the coming of Christ, the mysteries of our redemption, the calling of the Gentiles, and the glorious establishment, and perpetual flourishing of the church of Christ:  insomuch that he may seem to have been rather an evangelist than a prophet.  His very name is not without mystery; for Isaias in Hebrew signifies the salvation of the Lord, or Jesus is the Lord.  He was, according to the tradition of the Hebrews, of the blood royal of the kings of Juda:  and after a most holy life, ended his days by a glorious martyrdom; being sawed in two, at the command of his wicked son in law, King Manasses, for reproving his evil ways.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 1
ch.desc: The prophet complains of the sins of Juda and Jerusalem, and exhorts them to a sincere conversion.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 2
ch.desc: All nations shall flow to the church of Christ.  The Jews shall be rejected for their sins.  Idolatry shall be destroyed.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 3
ch.desc: The confusion and other evils that shall come upon the Jews for their sins.  The pride of their women shall be punished.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 4

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 5
ch.desc: The reprobation of the Jews is foreshewn under the parable of a vineyard.  A woe is pronounced against sinners:  the army of God shall send against them.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 6
ch.desc: A glorious vision, in which the prophet's lips are cleansed:  he foretelleth the obstinacy of the Jews.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 7
ch.desc: The prophet assures king Achaz that the two kings his enemies shall not take Jerusalem.  A virgin shall conceive and bear a son.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 8
ch.desc: The name of a child that is to be born:  many evils shall come upon the Jews for their sins.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 9
ch.desc: What joy shall come after afflictions by the birth and kingdom of Christ; which shall flourish for ever.  Judgments upon Israel for their sins.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 10
ch.desc: Woe to the makers of wicked laws.  The Assyrian shall be a rod for punishing Israel:  but for their pride they shall be destroyed:  and a remnant of Israel saved.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 11
ch.desc: Of the spiritual kingdom of Christ, to which all nations shall repair.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 12
ch.desc: A canticle of thanksgiving for the benefits of Christ.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 13
ch.desc: The desolation of Babylon.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 14
ch.desc: The restoration of Israel after their captivity.  The parable or song insulting over the king of Babylon.  A prophecy against the Philistines.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 15
ch.desc: A prophecy of the desolation of the Moabites.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 16
ch.desc: The prophet prayeth for Christ's coming.  The affliction of the Moabites for their pride.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 17
ch.desc: Judgments upon Damascus and Samaria.  The overthrow of the Assyrians.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 18
ch.desc: A woe to the Ethiopians, who fed Israel with vain hopes, their future conversion.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 19
ch.desc: The punishment of Egypt:  their call to the church.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 20
ch.desc: The ignominious captivity of the Egyptians, and the Ethiopians.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 21
ch.desc: The destruction of Babylon by the Medes and Persians:  a prophecy against the Edomites and the Arabians.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 22
ch.desc: The prophet laments the devastation of Juda.  He foretells the deprivation of Sobna, and the substitution of Eliacim, a figure of Christ.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 23
ch.desc: The destruction of Tyre.  It shall be repaired again after seventy years.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 24
ch.desc: The judgments of God upon all the sinners of the world.  A remnant shall joyfully praise him.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 25
ch.desc: A canticle of thanksgiving for God's judgments and benefits.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 26
ch.desc: A canticle of thanks for the deliverance of God's people.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 27
ch.desc: The punishment of the oppressors of God's people.  The Lord's favour to his church.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 28
ch.desc: The punishment of the Israelites, for their pride, intemperance, and contempt of religion.  Christ the cornerstone.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 29
ch.desc: God's heavy judgments upon Jerusalem, for their obstinacy:  with a prophecy of the conversion of the Gentiles.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 30
ch.desc: The people are blamed for their confidence in Egypt.  God's mercies towards his church.  The punishment of sinners.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 31
ch.desc: The folly of trusting to Egypt, and forgetting God.  He will fight for his people against the Assyrians.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 32
ch.desc: The blessings of the reign of Christ.  The desolation of the Jews, and prosperity of the church of Christ.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 33
ch.desc: God's revenge against the enemies of his church.  The happiness of the heavenly Jerusalem.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 34
ch.desc: The general judgment of the wicked.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 35
ch.desc: The joyful flourishing of Christ's kingdom:  in his church shall be a holy and secure way.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 36
ch.desc: Sennacherib invades Juda:  his blasphemies.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 37
ch.desc: Ezechias, his mourning and prayer.  God's promise of protection.  The Assyrian army is destroyed.  Sennacherib is slain.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 38
ch.desc: Ezechias being advertised that he shall die, obtains by prayer a prolongation of his life:  in confirmation of which the sun goes back. The canticle of Ezechias.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 39
ch.desc: Ezechias shews all his treasures to the ambassadors of Babylon:  upon which Isaias foretells the Babylonish captivity.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 40
ch.desc: The prophet comforts the people with the promise of the coming of Christ to forgive their sins.  God's almighty power and majesty.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 41
ch.desc: The reign of the just one:  the vanity of idols.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 42
ch.desc: The office of Christ.  The preaching of the gospel to the Gentiles.  The blindness and reprobation of the Jews.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 43
ch.desc: God comforts his church, promising to protect her for ever:  he expostulates with the Jews for their ingratitude.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 44
ch.desc: God's favour to his church.  The folly of idolatry.  The people shall be delivered from captivity.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 45
ch.desc: A prophecy of Cyrus, as a figure of Christ, the great deliverer of God's people.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 46
ch.desc: The idols of Babylon shall be destroyed.  Salvation is promised through Christ.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 47
ch.desc: God's judgment upon Babylon.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 48
ch.desc: He reproaches the Jews for their obstinacy:  he will deliver them out of their captivity, for his own name's sake.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 49
ch.desc: Christ shall bring the Gentiles to salvation.  God's love to his church is perpetual.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 50
ch.desc: The synagogue shall be divorced for her iniquities.  Christ for her sake will endure ignominious afflictions.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 51
ch.desc: An exhortation to trust in Christ.  He shall protect the children of his church.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 52
ch.desc: Under the figure of the deliverance from the Babylonish captivity, the church is invited to rejoice for her redemption from sin.  Christ's kingdom shall be exalted.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 53
ch.desc: A prophecy of the passion of Christ.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 54
ch.desc: The Gentiles, who were barren before, shall multiply in the church of Christ:  from which God's mercy shall never depart.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 55
ch.desc: God promises abundance of spiritual graces to the faithful, that shall believe in Christ out of all nations, and sincerely serve him.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 56
ch.desc: God invites all to keep his commandments:  the Gentiles that keep them shall be the people of God:  the Jewish pastors are reproved.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 57
ch.desc: The infidelity of the Jews:  their idolatry.  Promises to humble penitents.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 58
ch.desc: God rejects the hypocritical fasts of the Jews:  recommends works of mercy, and sincere godliness.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 59
ch.desc: The dreadful evil of sin is displayed, as the great obstacle to all good from God:  yet he will send a Redeemer, and make an everlasting covenant with his church.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 60
ch.desc: The light of true faith shall shine forth in the church of Christ, and shall be spread through all nations, and continue for all ages.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 61
ch.desc: The office of Christ:  the mission of the Apostles; the happiness of their converts.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 62
ch.desc: The prophet will not cease from preaching Christ:  to whom all nations shall be converted:  and whose church shall continue for ever.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 63
ch.desc: Christ's victory over his enemies:  his mercies to his people:  their complaint.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 64
ch.desc: The prophet prays for the release of his people; and for the remission of their sins.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 65
ch.desc: The Gentiles shall seek and find Christ, but the Jews will persecute him, and be rejected, only a remnant shall be reserved.  The church shall multiply, and abound with graces.

ch.name: Isaias Chapter 66
ch.desc: More of the reprobation of the Jews, and of the call of the Gentiles.

name: Prophecy of Jeremias
desc: Jeremias was a priest, a native of Anathoth, a priestly city in the tribe of Benjamin:  and was sanctified from his mother's womb, to be a prophet of God; which office he began to execute when he was yet a child in age.  He was in his whole life, according to the signification of his name, Great before the Lord; and a special figure of Jesus Christ, in the persecutions he underwent for discharging his duty; in his charity for his persecutors; and in the violent death he suffered at their hands:  it being an ancient tradition of the Hebrews, that he was stoned to death by the remnant of the Jews who had retired into Egypt.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 1
ch.desc: The time, and the calling, of Jeremias:  his prophetical visions.  God encourages him.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 2
ch.desc: God expostulates with the Jews for their ingratitude and infidelity.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 3
ch.desc: God invites the rebel Jews to return to him, with a promise to receive them:  he foretells the conversion of the Gentiles.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 4
ch.desc: And admonition to sincere repentance, and circumcision of the heart, with threats of grievous punishment to those that persist in sin.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 5
ch.desc: The judgments of God shall fall upon the Jews for their manifold sins.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 6
ch.desc: The evils that threaten Jerusalem.  She is invited to return, and walk in the good way, and not to rely on sacrifices without obedience.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 7
ch.desc: The temple of God shall not protect a sinful people, without a sincere conversion.  The Lord will not receive the prayers of the prophet for them:  because they are obstinate in their sins.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 8
ch.desc: Other evils that shall fall upon the Jews for their impenitence.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 9
ch.desc: The prophet laments the miseries of his people:  and their sins, which are the cause of them.  He exhorts them to repentance.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 10
ch.desc: Neither stars nor idols are to be feared, but the great Creator of all things.  The chastisement of Jerusalem for her sins.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 11
ch.desc: The prophet proclaims the covenant of God:  and denounces evils to the obstinate transgressors of it.  The conspiracy of the Jews against him, a figure of their conspiracy against Christ.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 12
ch.desc: The prosperity of the wicked shall be but for a short time.  The desolation of the Jews for their sins.  Their return from their captivity.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 13
ch.desc: Under the figure of a linen girdle is foretold the destruction of the Jews.  Their obstinacy in sin brings all miseries upon them.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 14
ch.desc: A grievous famine:  and the prophet's prayer on that occasion.  Evils denounced to false prophets.  The prophet mourns for his people.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 15
ch.desc: God is determined to punish the Jews for their sins.  The prophet's complaint, and God's promise to him.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 16
ch.desc: The prophet is forbid to marry.  The Jews shall be utterly ruined for their idolatry:  but shall at length be released from their captivity, and the Gentiles shall be converted.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 17
ch.desc: For their obstinacy in sin the Jews shall be led captive.  He is cursed that trusteth in flesh.  God alone searcheth the heart, giving to every one as he deserves.  The prophet prayeth to be delivered from his enemies, and preacheth up the observance of the sabbath.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 18
ch.desc: As the clay in the hand of the potter, so is Israel in God's hand.  He pardoneth penitents, and punisheth the obstinate.  They conspire against Jeremias, for which he denounceth to them the miseries that hang over them.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 19
ch.desc: Under the type of breaking a potter's vessel, the prophet foresheweth the desolation of the Jews for their sins.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 20
ch.desc: The prophet is persecuted:  he denounces captivity to his persecutors, and bemoans himself.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 21
ch.desc: The prophet's answer to the messengers of Sedecias, when Jerusalem was besieged.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 22
ch.desc: An exhortation both to king and people to return of God.  The sentence of God upon Joachaz, Joakim, and Jechonias.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 23
ch.desc: God reproves evil governors; and promises to send good pastors; and Christ himself the prince of the pastors.  He inveighs against false prophets preaching without being sent.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 24
ch.desc: Under the type of good and bad figs, he foretells the restoration of the Jews that had been carried away captive with Jechonias, and the desolation of those that were left behind.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 25
ch.desc: The prophet foretells the seventy years captivity; after that the destruction of Babylon, and other nations.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 26
ch.desc: The prophet is apprehended and accused by the priests:  but discharged by the princes.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 27
ch.desc: The prophet sends chains to divers kings, signifying that they must bend their necks under the yoke of the king of Babylon.  The vessels of the temple shall not be brought back till all the rest are carried away.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 28
ch.desc: The false prophecy of Hananias:  he dies that same year, as Jeremias foretold.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 29
ch.desc: Jeremias writeth to the captives in Babylon, exhorting them to be easy there, and not to hearken to false prophets.  That they shall be delivered after seventy years.  But those that remain in Jerusalem shall perish by the sword, famine, and pestilence.  And that Achab, Sedecias, and Semeias, false prophets, shall die miserably.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 30
ch.desc: God will deliver his people from their captivity:  Christ shall be their king:  and his church shall be glorious for ever.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 31
ch.desc: The restoration of Israel.  Rachel shall cease from morning.  The new covenant.  The church shall never fail.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 32
ch.desc: Jeremias by God's commandment purchases a field of his kinsman:  and prophesies the return of the people out of captivity:  and the everlasting covenant God will make with his church.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 33
ch.desc: God promises reduction from captivity, and other blessings:  especially the coming of Christ, whose reign in his church shall be glorious and perpetual.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 34
ch.desc: The prophet foretells that Sedecias shall fall into the hands of Nabuchodonosor:  God's sentence upon the princes and people that had broken his covenant.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 35
ch.desc: The obedience of the Rechabites condemns the disobedience of the Jews. The reward of the Rechabites.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 36
ch.desc: Jeremias sends Baruch to read his prophecies in the temple; the book is brought to king Joakim, who burns it.  The prophet denounces his judgment, and causes Baruch to write a new copy.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 37
ch.desc: Jeremias prophesies that the Chaldeans, who had departed from Jerusalem, would return and burn the city.  He is cast into prison.  His conference with Sedecias.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 38
ch.desc: The prophet at the instance of the great men is cast into a filthy dungeon:  he is drawn out by Abdemelech, and has another conference with the king.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 39
ch.desc: After two years' siege Jerusalem is taken.  Sedecias is carried before Nabuchodonosor, who kills his sons in his sight, and then puts out his eyes.  Jeremias is set at liberty.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 40
ch.desc: Jeremias remains with Godolias the governor; who receives all the Jews that resort to him.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 41
ch.desc: Godolias is slain:  the Jews that were with him are apprehensive of the Chaldeans.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 42
ch.desc: Jeremias assures the remnant of the people, that if they will stay in Juda, they shall be safe; but if they go down into Egypt, they shall perish.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 43
ch.desc: The Jews, contrary to the orders of God by the prophet, go into Egypt, carrying Jeremias with them.  He foretells the devastation of that land by the king of Babylon.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 44
ch.desc: The prophet's admonition to the Jews in Egypt against idolatry is not regarded:  he denounces to them their destruction.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 45
ch.desc: The prophet comforts Baruch in his affliction.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 46
ch.desc: A prophecy against Egypt.  The Jews shall return from captivity.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 47
ch.desc: A prophecy of the desolation of the Philistines, of Tyre, Sidon, Gaza, and Ascalon.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 48
ch.desc: A prophecy of the desolation of Moab for their pride:  but their captivity shall at last be released.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 49
ch.desc: The like desolation of Ammon, of Idumea, of the Syrians, of the Agarenes, and of the Elamites.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 50
ch.desc: Babylon, which hath afflicted the Israelites, after their restoration, shall be utterly destroyed.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 51
ch.desc: The miseries that shall fall upon Babylon from the Medes:  the destruction of her idols.

ch.name: Jeremias Chapter 52
ch.desc: A recapitulation of the reign of Sedecias, and the destruction of Jerusalem.  The number of the captives.

name: Lamentations of Jeremias
desc: In these JEREMIAS laments in a most pathetical manner the miseries of his people, and the destruction of JERUSALEM and the temple, in Hebrew verses, beginning with different letters according to the order of the Hebrew alphabet.

ch.name: Lamentations Chapter 1
ch.desc: PREFACE:  And it came to pass, after Israel was carried into captivity, and Jerusalem was desolate, that Jeremias the prophet sat weeping, and mourned with this lamentation over Jerusalem, and with a sorrowful mind, sighing and moaning, he said:
ch.chapternotes: And it came to pass, etc. . .This preface was not written by Jeremias, but was added by the seventy interpreters, to give the reader to understand upon what occasion the Lamentations were published.

name: Prophecy of Baruch
desc: BARUCH was a man of noble extraction, and learned in the law, secretary and disciple to the prophet JEREMIAS, and a sharer in his labours and persecutions:  which is the reason why the ancient fathers have considered this book as a part of the prophecy of JEREMIAS, and have usually quoted it under his name.

ch.name: Baruch Chapter 1
ch.desc: The Jews of Babylon send the book of Baruch with money to Jerusalem, requesting their brethren there to offer sacrifice, and to pray for the king and for them, acknowledging their manifold sins.

ch.name: Baruch Chapter 2
ch.desc: A further confession of the sins of the people, and of the justice of God.

ch.name: Baruch Chapter 3
ch.desc: They pray for mercy, acknowledging that they are justly punished for forsaking true wisdom.  A prophecy of Christ.

ch.name: Baruch Chapter 4
ch.desc: The prophet exhorts to the keeping of the law of wisdom, and encourages the people to be patient, and to hope for their deliverance.

ch.name: Baruch Chapter 5
ch.desc: Jerusalem is invited to rejoice and behold the return of her children out of their captivity.

ch.name: Baruch Chapter 6
ch.desc: The epistle of Jeremias to the captives, as a preservative against idolatry. A copy of the epistle that Jeremias sent to them that were to be led away captives into Babylon, by the king of Babylon, to declare to them according to what was commanded him by God.

name: Prophecy of Ezechiel
desc: EZECHIEL, whose name signifies the STRENGTH OF GOD, was of the priestly race; and of the number of captives that were carried away to Babylon with king JOACHIN.  He was contemporary with JEREMIAS, and prophesied to the same effect in Babylon, as JEREMIAS did in Jerusalem; and is said to have ended his days in like manner, by martyrdom.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 1
ch.desc: The time of Ezechiel's prophecy:  he sees a glorious vision.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 2
ch.desc: The prophet receives his commission.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 3
ch.desc: The prophet eats the book, and receives further instructions:  the office of a watchman.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 4
ch.desc: A prophetic description of the siege of Jerusalem, and the famine that shall reign there.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 5
ch.desc: The judgments of God upon the Jews are foreshewn under the type of the prophet's hair.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 6
ch.desc: The punishment of Israel for their idolatry:  a remnant shall be saved.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 7
ch.desc: The final desolation of Israel:  from which few shall escape.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 8
ch.desc: The prophet sees in a vision the abominations committed in Jerusalem; which determine the Lord to spare them no longer.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 9
ch.desc: All are ordered to be destroyed that are not marked in their foreheads. God will not be entreated for them.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 10
ch.desc: Fire is taken from the midst of the wheels under the cherubims, and scattered over the city.  A description of the cherubims.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 11
ch.desc: A prophecy against the presumptuous assurance of the great ones.  A remnant shall be saved, and receive a new spirit, and a new heart.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 12
ch.desc: The prophet forsheweth, by signs, the captivity of Sedecias, and the desolation of the people:  all which shall quickly come to pass.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 13
ch.desc: God declares against false prophets and prophetesses, that deceive the people with lies.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 14
ch.desc: God suffers the wicked to be deceived in punishment of their wickedness.  The evils that shall come upon them for their sins:  for which they shall not be delivered by the prayers of Noe, Daniel, and Job.  But a remnant shall be preserved.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 15
ch.desc: As a vine cut down is fit for nothing but the fire; so it shall be with Jerusalem, for her sins.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 16
ch.desc: Under the figure of an unfaithful wife, God upbraids Jerusalem with her ingratitude and manifold disloyalties:  but promiseth mercy by a new covenant.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 17
ch.desc: The parable of the two eagles and the vine.  A promise of the cedar of Christ and his church.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 18
ch.desc: One man shall not bear the sins of another, but every one his own; if a wicked man truly repent, he shall be saved; and if a just man leave his justice, he shall perish.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 19
ch.desc: The parable of the young lions, and of the vineyard that is wasted.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 20
ch.desc: God refuses to answer the ancients of Israel inquiring by the prophet: but by him setteth his benefits before their eyes, and their heinous sins:  threatening yet greater punishments:  but still mixed with mercy.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 21
ch.desc: The destruction of Jerusalem by the sword is further described:  the ruin also of the Ammonites is forshewn.  And finally Babylon, the destroyer of others, shall be destroyed.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 22
ch.desc: The general corruption of the inhabitants of Jerusalem:  for which God will consume them as dross in his furnace.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 23
ch.desc: Under the names of the two harlots, Oolla and Ooliba, are described the manifold disloyalties of Samaria and Jerusalem, with the punishment of them both.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 24
ch.desc: Under the parable of a boiling pot is shewn the utter destruction of Jerusalem:  for which the Jews at Babylon shall not dare to mourn.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 25
ch.desc: A prophecy against the Ammonites, Moabites, Edomites, and Philistines, for their malice against the Israelites.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 26
ch.desc: A prophecy of the destruction of the famous city of Tyre by Nabuchodonosor.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 27
ch.desc: A description of the glory and riches of Tyre:  and of her irrecoverable fall.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 28
ch.desc: The king of Tyre, who affected to be like to God, shall fall under the like sentence with Lucifer.  The judgment of Sidon.  The restoration of Israel.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 29
ch.desc: The king of Egypt shall be overthrown, and his kingdom wasted:  it shall be given to Nabuchodonosor for his service against Tyre.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 30
ch.desc: The desolation of Egypt and her helpers:  all her cities shall be wasted.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 31
ch.desc: The Assyrian empire fell for their pride:  the Egyptian shall fall in like manner.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 32
ch.desc: The prophet's lamentation for the king of Egypt.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 33
ch.desc: The duty of the watchman appointed by God:  the justice of God's ways: his judgments upon the Jews.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 34
ch.desc: Evil pastors are reproved.  Christ the true pastor shall come, and gather together his flock from all parts of the earth, and preserve it for ever.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 35
ch.desc: The judgment of mount Seir, for their hatred of Israel.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 36
ch.desc: The restoration of Israel, not for their merits, but by God's special grace.  Christ's baptism.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 37
ch.desc: A vision of the resurrection of dry bones, foreshewing the deliverance of the people from their captivity.  Juda and Israel shall be all one kingdom under Christ.  God's everlasting covenant with the church.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 38
ch.desc: Gog shall persecute the church in the latter days.  He shall be overthrown.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 39
ch.desc: God's judgments upon Gog.  God's people were punished for their sins: but shall be favoured with everlasting kindness.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 40
ch.desc: The prophet sees in a vision the rebuilding of the temple:  the dimensions of several parts thereof.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 41
ch.desc: A description of the temple, and of all the parts of it.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 42
ch.desc: A description of the courts, chambers, and other places belonging to the temple.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 43
ch.desc: The glory of God returns to the new temple.  The Israelites shall no more profane God's name by idolatry:  the prophet is commanded to shew them the dimensions, and form of the temple, and of the altar, with the sacrifices to be offered thereon.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 44
ch.desc: The east gate of the sanctuary shall be always shut.  The uncircumcised shall not enter into the sanctuary:  nor the Levites that have served idols:  but the sons of Sadoc shall do the priestly functions, who stood firm in the worst of times.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 45
ch.desc: Portions of land for the sanctuary, for the city, and for the prince. Ordinances for the prince.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 46
ch.desc: Other ordinances for the prince and for the sacrifices.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 47
ch.desc: The vision of the holy waters issuing out from under the temple:  the borders of the land to be divided among the twelve tribes.

ch.name: Ezechiel Chapter 48
ch.desc: The portions of the twelve tribes, of the sanctuary, of the city, and of the prince.  The dimensions and gates of the city.

name: Prophecy of Daniel
desc: DANIEL, whose name signifies THE JUDGMENT OF GOD, was of the royal blood of the kings of Juda:  and one of those that were first of all carried away into captivity.  He was so renowned for wisdom and knowledge, that it became a proverb among the Babylonians, AS WISE AS DANIEL (Ezech. 28.3).  And his holiness was so great from his very childhood, that at the time when he was as yet but a young man, he is joined by the SPIRIT of GOD with NOE and JOB, as three persons most eminent for virtue and sanctity, Ezech. 14.  He is not commonly numbered by the Hebrews among THE PROPHETS:  because he lived at court, and in high station in the world:  but if we consider his many clear predictions of things to come, we shall find that no one better deserves the name and title of A PROPHET:  which also has been given him by the SON of GOD himself, Matt. 24, Mark 13., Luke 21.

ch.name: Daniel Chapter 1
ch.desc: Daniel and his companions are taken into the palace of the king of Babylon:  they abstain from his meat and wine, and succeed better with pulse and water.  Their excellence and wisdom.

ch.name: Daniel Chapter 2
ch.desc: Daniel, by divine revelation, declares the dream of Nabuchodonosor, and the interpretation of it.  He is highly honoured by the king.

ch.name: Daniel Chapter 3
ch.desc: Nabuchodonosor set up a golden statue; which he commands all to adore: the three children for refusing to do it are cast into the fiery furnace; but are not hurt by the flames.  Their prayer and canticle of praise.

ch.name: Daniel Chapter 4
ch.desc: Nabuchodonosor's dream, by which the judgments of God are denounced against him for his pride, is interpreted by Daniel, and verified by the event.

ch.name: Daniel Chapter 5
ch.desc: Baltasar's profane banquet:  his sentence is denounced by a handwriting on the wall, which Daniel reads and interprets.

ch.name: Daniel Chapter 6
ch.desc: Daniel is promoted by Darius:  his enemies procure a law forbidding prayer; for the transgression of this law Daniel is cast into the lions' den:  but miraculously delivered.

ch.name: Daniel Chapter 7
ch.desc: Daniel's vision of the four beasts, signifying four kingdoms:  of God sitting on his throne:  and of the opposite kingdoms of Christ and Antichrist.

ch.name: Daniel Chapter 8
ch.desc: Daniel's vision of the ram and the he goat interpreted by the angel Gabriel.

ch.name: Daniel Chapter 9
ch.desc: Daniel's confession and prayer:  Gabriel informs him concerning the seventy weeks to the coming of Christ.

ch.name: Daniel Chapter 10
ch.desc: Daniel having humbled himself by fasting and penance seeth a vision, with which he is much terrified; but he is comforted by an angel.

ch.name: Daniel Chapter 11
ch.desc: The angel declares to Daniel many things to come, with regard to the Persian and Grecian kings:  more especially with regard to Antiochus as a figure of Antichrist.

ch.name: Daniel Chapter 12
ch.desc: Michael shall stand up for the people of God:  with other things relating to Antichrist, and the end of the world.

ch.name: Daniel Chapter 13
ch.desc: The history of Susanna and the two elders. This history of Susanna, in all the ancient Greek and Latin Bibles, was placed in the beginning of the book of Daniel:  till St. Jerome, in his translation, detached it from thence; because he did not find it in the Hebrew:  which is also the case of the history of Bel and the Dragon. But both the one and the other are received by the Catholic Church:  and were from the very beginning a part of the Christian Bible.

ch.name: Daniel Chapter 14
ch.desc: The history of Bel, and of the great serpent worshipped by the Babylonians.

name: Prophecy of Osee
desc: OSEE, or Hosea, whose name signifies A saviour, was the first in the order of time among those who are commonly called lesser prophets, because their prophecies are short.  He prophesied in the kingdom of Israel, that is, of the ten tribes, about the same time that Isaias prophesied in the kingdom of Juda.

ch.name: Osee Chapter 1
ch.desc: By marrying a harlot, and by the names of his children, the prophet sets forth the crimes of Israel and their punishment.  He foretells their redemption by Christ.

ch.name: Osee Chapter 2
ch.desc: Israel is justly punished for leaving God.  The abundance of grace in the church of Christ.

ch.name: Osee Chapter 3
ch.desc: The prophet is commanded again to love an adulteress; to signify God's love to the synagogue.  The wretched state of the Jews for a long time, till at last they shall be converted.

ch.name: Osee Chapter 4
ch.desc: God's judgment against the sins of Israel:  Juda is warned not to follow their example.

ch.name: Osee Chapter 5
ch.desc: God's threats against the priests, the people, and princes of Israel, for their idolatry.

ch.name: Osee Chapter 6
ch.desc: Affliction shall be a means to bring many to Christ, a complaint of the untowardness of the Jews.  God loves mercy more than sacrifice.

ch.name: Osee Chapter 7
ch.desc: The manifold sins of Israel, and of their kings, hinder the Lord from healing them.

ch.name: Osee Chapter 8
ch.desc: The Israelites are threatened with destruction for their impiety and idolatry.

ch.name: Osee Chapter 9
ch.desc: The distress and captivity of Israel for their sins and idolatry.

ch.name: Osee Chapter 10
ch.desc: After many benefits, great affliction shall fall upon the ten tribes, for their ingratitude to God.

ch.name: Osee Chapter 11
ch.desc: God proceeds in threatening Israel for their ingratitude:  yet he will not utterly destroy them.

ch.name: Osee Chapter 12
ch.desc: Israel is reproved for sin.  God's favours to them.

ch.name: Osee Chapter 13
ch.desc: The judgments of God upon Israel for their sins.  Christ shall one day redeem them.

ch.name: Osee Chapter 14
ch.desc: Samaria shall be destroyed.  An exhortation to repentance:  God's favour through Christ to the penitent.

name: Prophecy of Joel
desc: JOEL, whose name, according to ST. JEROME, signifies THE LORD GOD:  or, as others say, THE COMING DOWN OF GOD:  prophesied about the same time in the kingdom of Judea, as OSEE did in the kingdom of Israel.  He foretells under figure the great evils that were coming upon the people for their sins:  earnestly exhorts them to repentance:  and comforts them with the promise of a TEACHER OF JUSTICE, viz., CHRIST JESUS OUR LORD, and of the coming down of his holy SPIRIT.

ch.name: Joel Chapter 1
ch.desc: The prophet describes the judgments that shall fall upon the people, and invites them to fasting and prayer.

name: Prophecy of Amos
desc: AMOS prophesied in Israel about the same time as OSEE:  and was called from following the cattle to denounce GOD'S judgments to the people of Israel, and the neighbouring nations, for their repeated crimes, in which they continued without repentance.

ch.name: Amos Chapter 1
ch.desc: The prophet threatens Damascus, Gaza, Tyre, Edom, and Ammon with the judgments of God, for their obstinacy in sin.

ch.name: Amos Chapter 2
ch.desc: The judgments with which God threatens Moab, Juda, and Israel for their sins, and their ingratitude.

ch.name: Amos Chapter 3
ch.desc: The evils that shall fall upon Israel for their sins.

ch.name: Amos Chapter 4
ch.desc: The Israelites are reproved for their oppressing the poor, for their idolatry, and their incorrigibleness.

ch.name: Amos Chapter 5
ch.desc: A lamentation for Israel:  an exhortation to return to God.

ch.name: Amos Chapter 6
ch.desc: The desolation of Israel for their pride and luxury.

ch.name: Amos Chapter 7
ch.desc: The prophet sees, in three visions, evils coming upon Israel:  he is accused of treason by the false priest of Bethel.

ch.name: Amos Chapter 8
ch.desc: Under the figure of a hook, which bringeth down the fruit, the approaching desolation of Israel is foreshewed for their avarice and injustices.

ch.name: Amos Chapter 9
ch.desc: The certainty of the desolation of Israel:  the restoring of the tabernacle of David, and the conversion of the Gentiles to the church; which shall flourish for ever.

name: Prophecy of Abdias
desc: ABDIAS, whose name is interpreted THE SERVANT OF THE LORD, is believed to have prophesied about the same time as OSEE, JOEL, and AMOS:  though some of the Hebrews, who believe him to be the same with ACHAB's steward, make him much more ancient.  His prophecy is the shortest of any in number of words, but yields to none, says ST. JEROME, in the sublimity of mysteries.  It contains but one chapter.

ch.name: Abdias Chapter 1
ch.desc: The destruction of Edom for their pride:  and the wrongs they did to Jacob:  the salvation and victory of Israel.

name: Prophecy of Jonas
desc: JONAS prophesied in the reign of JEREBOAM the second:  as we learn from 4 Kings 14.25. To whom also he foretold his success in restoring all the borders of Israel.  He was of GETH OPHER in the tribe of ZABULON, and consequently of GALILEE:  which confutes that assertion of the Pharisees, John 7.52, that no prophet ever rose out of GALILEE.  He prophesied and prefigured in his own person the death and resurrection of CHRIST:  and was the only one among the prophets that was sent to preach to the Gentiles.

ch.name: Jonas Chapter 1
ch.desc: Jonas being sent to preach in Ninive, fleeth away by sea:  a tempest riseth:  of which he being found, by lot, to be the cause, is cast into the sea, which thereupon is calmed.

ch.name: Jonas Chapter 2
ch.desc: Jonas is swallowed up by a great fish:  he prayeth with confidence in God; and the fish casteth him out on the dry land.

ch.name: Jonas Chapter 3
ch.desc: Jonas is sent again to preach in Ninive.  Upon their fasting and repentance, God recalleth the sentence by which they were to be destroyed.

name: Prophecy of Micheas
desc: MICHEAS, of Morasti, a little town in the tribe of JUDA, was contemporary with the prophet ISAIAS:  whom he resembles both in his spirit and his style.  He is different from the prophet MICHEAS mentioned in the third book of Kings, chap. 22.  For that MICHEAS lived in the days of king ACHAB, one hundred and fifty years before the time of EZECHIAS, under whom this MICHEAS prophesied.

ch.name: Micheas Chapter 1
ch.desc: Samaria for her sins shall be destroyed by the Assyrians; they shall also invade Juda and Jerusalem.

ch.name: Micheas Chapter 2
ch.desc: The Israelites by their crying injustices provoke God to punish them. He shall at last restore Jacob.

ch.name: Micheas Chapter 3
ch.desc: For the sins of the rich oppressing the poor, of false prophets flattering for lucre, and of judges perverting justice, Jerusalem and the temple shall be destroyed.

ch.name: Micheas Chapter 4
ch.desc: The glory of the church of Christ, by the conversion of the Gentiles. The Jews shall be carried captives to Babylon, and be delivered again.

ch.name: Micheas Chapter 5
ch.desc: The birth of Christ in Bethlehem:  his reign and spiritual conquests.

ch.name: Micheas Chapter 6
ch.desc: God expostulates with the Jews for their ingratitude and sins:  for which they shall be punished.

ch.name: Micheas Chapter 7
ch.desc: The prophet laments, that notwithstanding all his preaching, the generality are still corrupt in their manners:  therefore their desolation is at hand:  but they shall be restored again and prosper; and all mankind shall be redeemed by Christ.

name: Prophecy of Nahum
desc: NAHUM, whose name signifies A COMFORTER, was a native of Elcese, or Elcesai, supposed to be a little town in Galilee.  He prophesied, after the ten tribes were carried into captivity, and foretold the utter destruction of Ninive, by the Babylonians and Medes:  which happened in the reign of JOSIAS.

ch.name: Nahum Chapter 1
ch.desc: The majesty of God, his goodness to his people, and severity to his enemies.

ch.name: Nahum Chapter 2
ch.desc: God sends his armies against Ninive to destroy it.

ch.name: Nahum Chapter 3
ch.desc: The miserable destruction of Ninive.

name: Prophecy of Habacuc
desc: HABACUC was a native of Bezocher, and prophesied in JUDA, some time before the invasion of the CHALDEANS, which he foretold.  He lived to see this prophecy fulfilled, and for many years after, according to the general opinion, which supposes him to be the same that was brought by the ANGEL to DANIEL in BABYLON, Dan. 14.

ch.name: Habacuc Chapter 1
ch.desc: The prophet complains of the wickedness of the people:  God reveals to him the vengeance he is going to take of them by the Chaldeans.

ch.name: Habacuc Chapter 2
ch.desc: The prophet is admonished to wait with faith.  The enemies of God's people shall assuredly be punished.

name: Prophecy of Sophonias
desc: SOPHONIAS, whose name, saith St. Jerome, signifies The Watchman of the Lord, or The hidden of the Lord, prophesied in the beginning of the reign of Josias.  He was a native of Sarabatha, and of the tribe of Simeon, according to the more general opinion.  He prophesied the punishments of the Jews, for their idolatry and other crimes; also the punishments that were to come on divers nations; the coming of Christ, the conversion of the Gentiles, the blindness of the Jews, and their conversion towards the end of the world.

ch.name: Sophonias Chapter 1
ch.desc: For divers enormous sins, the kingdom of Juda is threatened with severe judgment.

ch.name: Sophonias Chapter 2
ch.desc: An exhortation to repentance.  The judgment of the Philistines, of the Moabites, and the Ammonites; of the Ethiopians and the Assyrians.

ch.name: Sophonias Chapter 3
ch.desc: A woe to Jerusalem for her sins.  A prophecy of the conversion of the Gentiles, and of the poor of Israel:  God shall be with them.  The Jews shall be converted at last.

name: Prophecy of Aggeus
desc: AGGEUS was one of those that returned from the captivity of Babylon, in the first year of the reign of king Cyrus.  He was sent by the Lord, in the second year of the reign of king Darius, the son of Hystaspes, to exhort Zorobabel the prince of Juda, and Jesus the high priest, to the building of the temple; which they had begun, but left off again through the opposition of the Samaritans.  In consequence of this exhortation they proceeded in the building and finished the temple.  And the prophet was commissioned by the Lord to assure them that this second temple should be more glorious than the former, because the Messiah should honour it with his presence:  signifying withal how much the church of the New Testament should excel that of the Old Testament.

ch.name: Aggeus Chapter 1
ch.desc: The people are reproved for neglecting to build the temple.  They are encouraged to set about the work.

ch.name: Aggeus Chapter 2
ch.desc: Christ by his coming shall make the latter temple more glorious than the former.  The blessing of God shall reward their labour in building. God's promise to Zorobabel.

name: Prophecy of Zacharias
